 2191:         """
 2192:         pareto(a, size=None)
 2193: 
 2194:         Draw samples from a Pareto II or Lomax distribution with
 2195:         specified shape.
 2196: 
 2197:         The Lomax or Pareto II distribution is a shifted Pareto
 2198:         distribution. The classical Pareto distribution can be
 2199:         obtained from the Lomax distribution by adding 1 and
 2200:         multiplying by the scale parameter ``m`` (see Notes). The
 2201:         smallest value of the Lomax distribution is zero while for the
 2202:         classical Pareto distribution it is ``mu``, where the standard
 2203:         Pareto distribution has location ``mu = 1``. Lomax can also
 2204:         be considered as a simplified version of the Generalized
 2205:         Pareto distribution (available in SciPy), with the scale set
 2206:         to one and the location set to zero.
 2207: 
 2208:         The Pareto distribution must be greater than zero, and is
 2209:         unbounded above. It is also known as the "80-20 rule". In
 2210:         this distribution, 80 percent of the weights are in the lowest
 2211:         20 percent of the range, while the other 20 percent fill the
 2212:         remaining 80 percent of the range.
 2213: 
 2214:         Parameters
 2215:         ----------
 2216:         a : float or array_like of floats
 2217:             Shape of the distribution. Must be positive.
 2218:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2219:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2220:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2221:             a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 2222:             ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.
 2223: 
 2224:         Returns
 2225:         -------
 2226:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2227:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Pareto distribution.
 2228: 
 2229:         See Also
 2230:         --------
 2231:         scipy.stats.lomax : probability density function, distribution or
 2232:             cumulative density function, etc.
 2233:         scipy.stats.genpareto : probability density function, distribution or
 2234:             cumulative density function, etc.
 2235: 
 2236:         Notes
 2237:         -----
 2238:         The probability density for the Pareto distribution is
 2239: 
 2240:         .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{am^a}{x^{a+1}}
 2241: 
 2242:         where :math:`a` is the shape and :math:`m` the scale.
 2243: 
 2244:         The Pareto distribution, named after the Italian economist
 2245:         Vilfredo Pareto, is a power law probability distribution
 2246:         useful in many real world problems. Outside the field of
 2247:         economics it is generally referred to as the Bradford
 2248:         distribution. Pareto developed the distribution to describe
 2249:         the distribution of wealth in an economy. It has also found
 2250:         use in insurance, web page access statistics, oil field sizes,
 2251:         and many other problems, including the download frequency for
 2252:         projects in Sourceforge [1]_. It is one of the so-called
 2253:         "fat-tailed" distributions.
 2254: 
 2255:         References
 2256:         ----------
 2257:         .. [1] Francis Hunt and Paul Johnson, On the Pareto Distribution of
 2258:                Sourceforge projects.
 2259:         .. [2] Pareto, V. (1896). Course of Political Economy. Lausanne.
 2260:         .. [3] Reiss, R.D., Thomas, M.(2001), Statistical Analysis of Extreme
 2261:                Values, Birkhauser Verlag, Basel, pp 23-30.
 2262:         .. [4] Wikipedia, "Pareto distribution",
 2263:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pareto_distribution
 2264: 
 2265:         Examples
 2266:         --------
 2267:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 2268: 
 2269:         >>> a, m = 3., 2. # shape and mode
 2270:         >>> s = (randomgen.generator.pareto(a, 1000) + 1) * m
 2271: 
 2272:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with the probability
 2273:         density function:
 2274: 
 2275:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2276:         >>> count, bins, _ = plt.hist(s, 100, density=True)
 2277:         >>> fit = a*m**a / bins**(a+1)
 2278:         >>> plt.plot(bins, max(count)*fit/max(fit), linewidth=2, color='r')
 2279:         >>> plt.show()
 2280: 
 2281:         """
+2282:         return cont(&random_pareto, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 1,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/*  */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&random_pareto), (&__pyx_v_self->_bitgen), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 1, __pyx_v_a, __pyx_n_u_a, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_POSITIVE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__11, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__11, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 2282, __pyx_L1_error)

  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 2284:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE,

+2287:     def weibull(self, a, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_71weibull(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_70weibull[] = "\n        weibull(a, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Weibull distribution.\n\n        Draw samples from a 1-parameter Weibull distribution with the given\n        shape parameter `a`.\n\n        .. math:: X = (-ln(U))^{1/a}\n\n        Here, U is drawn from the uniform distribution over (0,1].\n\n        The more common 2-parameter Weibull, including a scale parameter\n        :math:`\\lambda` is just :math:`X = \\lambda(-ln(U))^{1/a}`.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        a : float or array_like of floats\n            Shape parameter of the distribution. Must be nonnegative.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Weibull distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.weibull_max\n        scipy.stats.weibull_min\n        scipy.stats.genextreme\n        gumbel\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The Weibull (or Type III asymptotic extreme value distribution\n        for smallest values, SEV Type III, or Rosin-Rammler\n        distribution) is one of a class of Generalized Extreme Value\n        (GEV) distributions used in modeling extreme value problems.\n        This class includes the Gumbel and Frechet distributions.\n\n        The probability density for the Weibull distribution is\n\n        .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{a}\n                         {\\lambda}(\\frac{x}{\\lambda})^{a-1}e^{-(x/\\lambda)^a},\n\n        where :math:`a` is the shape and :math:`\\lambda` the scale.\n\n        The function has its peak (the mode) at\n        :math:`\\lambda(\\frac{a-1}{a})^{1/a}`.\n\n        When ``a = 1``, the Weibull dis""tribution reduces to the exponential\n        distribution.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Waloddi Weibull, Royal Technical University, Stockholm,\n               1939 \"A Statistical Theory Of The Strength Of Materials\",\n               Ingeniorsvetenskapsakademiens Handlingar Nr 151, 1939,\n               Generalstabens Litografiska Anstalts Forlag, Stockholm.\n        .. [2] Waloddi Weibull, \"A Statistical Distribution Function of\n               Wide Applicability\", Journal Of Applied Mechanics ASME Paper\n               1951.\n        .. [3] Wikipedia, \"Weibull distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weibull_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> a = 5. # shape\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.weibull(a, 1000)\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> x = np.arange(1,100.)/50.\n        >>> def weib(x,n,a):\n        ...     return (a / n) * (x / n)**(a - 1) * np.exp(-(x / n)**a)\n\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(randomgen.generator.weibull(5.,1000))\n        >>> x = np.arange(1,100.)/50.\n        >>> scale = count.max()/weib(x, 1., 5.).max()\n        >>> plt.plot(x, weib(x, 1., 5.)*scale)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 2288:         """
 2289:         weibull(a, size=None)
 2290: 
 2291:         Draw samples from a Weibull distribution.
 2292: 
 2293:         Draw samples from a 1-parameter Weibull distribution with the given
 2294:         shape parameter `a`.
 2295: 
 2296:         .. math:: X = (-ln(U))^{1/a}
 2297: 
 2298:         Here, U is drawn from the uniform distribution over (0,1].
 2299: 
 2300:         The more common 2-parameter Weibull, including a scale parameter
 2301:         :math:`\\lambda` is just :math:`X = \\lambda(-ln(U))^{1/a}`.
 2302: 
 2303:         Parameters
 2304:         ----------
 2305:         a : float or array_like of floats
 2306:             Shape parameter of the distribution. Must be nonnegative.
 2307:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2308:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2309:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2310:             a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 2311:             ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.
 2312: 
 2313:         Returns
 2314:         -------
 2315:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2316:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Weibull distribution.
 2317: 
 2318:         See Also
 2319:         --------
 2320:         scipy.stats.weibull_max
 2321:         scipy.stats.weibull_min
 2322:         scipy.stats.genextreme
 2323:         gumbel
 2324: 
 2325:         Notes
 2326:         -----
 2327:         The Weibull (or Type III asymptotic extreme value distribution
 2328:         for smallest values, SEV Type III, or Rosin-Rammler
 2329:         distribution) is one of a class of Generalized Extreme Value
 2330:         (GEV) distributions used in modeling extreme value problems.
 2331:         This class includes the Gumbel and Frechet distributions.
 2332: 
 2333:         The probability density for the Weibull distribution is
 2334: 
 2335:         .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{a}
 2336:                          {\\lambda}(\\frac{x}{\\lambda})^{a-1}e^{-(x/\\lambda)^a},
 2337: 
 2338:         where :math:`a` is the shape and :math:`\\lambda` the scale.
 2339: 
 2340:         The function has its peak (the mode) at
 2341:         :math:`\\lambda(\\frac{a-1}{a})^{1/a}`.
 2342: 
 2343:         When ``a = 1``, the Weibull distribution reduces to the exponential
 2344:         distribution.
 2345: 
 2346:         References
 2347:         ----------
 2348:         .. [1] Waloddi Weibull, Royal Technical University, Stockholm,
 2349:                1939 "A Statistical Theory Of The Strength Of Materials",
 2350:                Ingeniorsvetenskapsakademiens Handlingar Nr 151, 1939,
 2351:                Generalstabens Litografiska Anstalts Forlag, Stockholm.
 2352:         .. [2] Waloddi Weibull, "A Statistical Distribution Function of
 2353:                Wide Applicability", Journal Of Applied Mechanics ASME Paper
 2354:                1951.
 2355:         .. [3] Wikipedia, "Weibull distribution",
 2356:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weibull_distribution
 2357: 
 2358:         Examples
 2359:         --------
 2360:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 2361: 
 2362:         >>> a = 5. # shape
 2363:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.weibull(a, 1000)
 2364: 
 2365:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 2366:         the probability density function:
 2367: 
 2368:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2369:         >>> x = np.arange(1,100.)/50.
 2370:         >>> def weib(x,n,a):
 2371:         ...     return (a / n) * (x / n)**(a - 1) * np.exp(-(x / n)**a)
 2372: 
 2373:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(randomgen.generator.weibull(5.,1000))
 2374:         >>> x = np.arange(1,100.)/50.
 2375:         >>> scale = count.max()/weib(x, 1., 5.).max()
 2376:         >>> plt.plot(x, weib(x, 1., 5.)*scale)
 2377:         >>> plt.show()
 2378: 
 2379:         """
+2380:         return cont(&random_weibull, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 1,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);

 2382:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE,

 2384: 
+2385:     def power(self, a, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_73power(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_72power[] = "\n        power(a, size=None)\n\n        Draws samples in [0, 1] from a power distribution with positive\n        exponent a - 1.\n\n        Also known as the power function distribution.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        a : float or array_like of floats\n            Parameter of the distribution. Must be non-negative.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized power distribution.\n\n        Raises\n        ------\n        ValueError\n            If a < 1.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density function is\n\n        .. math:: P(x; a) = ax^{a-1}, 0 \\le x \\le 1, a>0.\n\n        The power function distribution is just the inverse of the Pareto\n        distribution. It may also be seen as a special case of the Beta\n        distribution.\n\n        It is used, for example, in modeling the over-reporting of insurance\n        claims.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Christian Kleiber, Samuel Kotz, \"Statistical size distributions\n               in economics and actuarial sciences\", Wiley, 2003.\n        .. [2] Heckert, N. A. and Filliben, James J. \"NIST Handbook 148:\n               Dataplot Reference Manual, Volume 2: Let Subcommands and Library\n               Functions\", National Institute of Standards and Technology\n               Handbook Series, June 2003.\n               https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/software/dataplot/refman2/auxillar/powpdf.pdf\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> a = 5. # shape\n        >>> samples = 1000\n      ""  >>> s = randomgen.generator.power(a, samples)\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, bins=30)\n        >>> x = np.linspace(0, 1, 100)\n        >>> y = a*x**(a-1.)\n        >>> normed_y = samples*np.diff(bins)[0]*y\n        >>> plt.plot(x, normed_y)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        Compare the power function distribution to the inverse of the Pareto.\n\n        >>> from scipy import stats  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> rvs = randomgen.generator.power(5, 1000000)\n        >>> rvsp = randomgen.generator.pareto(5, 1000000)\n        >>> xx = np.linspace(0,1,100)\n        >>> powpdf = stats.powerlaw.pdf(xx,5)  # doctest: +SKIP\n\n        >>> plt.figure()\n        >>> plt.hist(rvs, bins=50, density=True)\n        >>> plt.plot(xx,powpdf,'r-')  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.title('randomgen.generator.power(5)')\n\n        >>> plt.figure()\n        >>> plt.hist(1./(1.+rvsp), bins=50, density=True)\n        >>> plt.plot(xx,powpdf,'r-')  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.title('inverse of 1 + randomgen.generator.pareto(5)')\n\n        >>> plt.figure()\n        >>> plt.hist(1./(1.+rvsp), bins=50, density=True)\n        >>> plt.plot(xx,powpdf,'r-')  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.title('inverse of stats.pareto(5)')\n\n        ";

 2386:         """
 2387:         power(a, size=None)
 2388: 
 2389:         Draws samples in [0, 1] from a power distribution with positive
 2390:         exponent a - 1.
 2391: 
 2392:         Also known as the power function distribution.
 2393: 
 2394:         Parameters
 2395:         ----------
 2396:         a : float or array_like of floats
 2397:             Parameter of the distribution. Must be non-negative.
 2398:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2399:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2400:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2401:             a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 2402:             ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.
 2403: 
 2404:         Returns
 2405:         -------
 2406:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2407:             Drawn samples from the parameterized power distribution.
 2408: 
 2409:         Raises
 2410:         ------
 2411:         ValueError
 2412:             If a < 1.
 2413: 
 2414:         Notes
 2415:         -----
 2416:         The probability density function is
 2417: 
 2418:         .. math:: P(x; a) = ax^{a-1}, 0 \\le x \\le 1, a>0.
 2419: 
 2420:         The power function distribution is just the inverse of the Pareto
 2421:         distribution. It may also be seen as a special case of the Beta
 2422:         distribution.
 2423: 
 2424:         It is used, for example, in modeling the over-reporting of insurance
 2425:         claims.
 2426: 
 2427:         References
 2428:         ----------
 2429:         .. [1] Christian Kleiber, Samuel Kotz, "Statistical size distributions
 2430:                in economics and actuarial sciences", Wiley, 2003.
 2431:         .. [2] Heckert, N. A. and Filliben, James J. "NIST Handbook 148:
 2432:                Dataplot Reference Manual, Volume 2: Let Subcommands and Library
 2433:                Functions", National Institute of Standards and Technology
 2434:                Handbook Series, June 2003.
 2435:                https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/software/dataplot/refman2/auxillar/powpdf.pdf
 2436: 
 2437:         Examples
 2438:         --------
 2439:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 2440: 
 2441:         >>> a = 5. # shape
 2442:         >>> samples = 1000
 2443:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.power(a, samples)
 2444: 
 2445:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 2446:         the probability density function:
 2447: 
 2448:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2449:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, bins=30)
 2450:         >>> x = np.linspace(0, 1, 100)
 2451:         >>> y = a*x**(a-1.)
 2452:         >>> normed_y = samples*np.diff(bins)[0]*y
 2453:         >>> plt.plot(x, normed_y)
 2454:         >>> plt.show()
 2455: 
 2456:         Compare the power function distribution to the inverse of the Pareto.
 2457: 
 2458:         >>> from scipy import stats  # doctest: +SKIP
 2459:         >>> rvs = randomgen.generator.power(5, 1000000)
 2460:         >>> rvsp = randomgen.generator.pareto(5, 1000000)
 2461:         >>> xx = np.linspace(0,1,100)
 2462:         >>> powpdf = stats.powerlaw.pdf(xx,5)  # doctest: +SKIP
 2463: 
 2464:         >>> plt.figure()
 2465:         >>> plt.hist(rvs, bins=50, density=True)
 2466:         >>> plt.plot(xx,powpdf,'r-')  # doctest: +SKIP
 2467:         >>> plt.title('randomgen.generator.power(5)')
 2468: 
 2469:         >>> plt.figure()
 2470:         >>> plt.hist(1./(1.+rvsp), bins=50, density=True)
 2471:         >>> plt.plot(xx,powpdf,'r-')  # doctest: +SKIP
 2472:         >>> plt.title('inverse of 1 + randomgen.generator.pareto(5)')
 2473: 
 2474:         >>> plt.figure()
 2475:         >>> plt.hist(1./(1.+rvsp), bins=50, density=True)
 2476:         >>> plt.plot(xx,powpdf,'r-')  # doctest: +SKIP
 2477:         >>> plt.title('inverse of stats.pareto(5)')
 2478: 
 2479:         """
+2480:         return cont(&random_power, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 1,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/*  */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&random_power), (&__pyx_v_self->_bitgen), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 1, __pyx_v_a, __pyx_n_u_a, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_POSITIVE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__11, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__11, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 2480, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 2482:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE,

+2485:     def laplace(self, loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_75laplace(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_74laplace[] = "\n        laplace(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from the Laplace or double exponential distribution with\n        specified location (or mean) and scale (decay).\n\n        The Laplace distribution is similar to the Gaussian/normal distribution,\n        but is sharper at the peak and has fatter tails. It represents the\n        difference between two independent, identically distributed exponential\n        random variables.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        loc : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            The position, :math:`\\mu`, of the distribution peak. Default is 0.\n        scale : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            :math:`\\lambda`, the exponential decay. Default is 1. Must be non-\n            negative.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``loc`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(loc, scale).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Laplace distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        It has the probability density function\n\n        .. math:: f(x; \\mu, \\lambda) = \\frac{1}{2\\lambda}\n                                       \\exp\\left(-\\frac{|x - \\mu|}{\\lambda}\\right).\n\n        The first law of Laplace, from 1774, states that the frequency\n        of an error can be expressed as an exponential function of the\n        absolute magnitude of the error, which leads to the Laplace\n        distribution. For many problems in economics and health\n        sciences, this distribution seems to model the data better\n        than the standard Gaussian distribution.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Abramowitz, ""M. and Stegun, I. A. (Eds.). \"Handbook of\n               Mathematical Functions with Formulas, Graphs, and Mathematical\n               Tables, 9th printing,\" New York: Dover, 1972.\n        .. [2] Kotz, Samuel, et. al. \"The Laplace Distribution and\n               Generalizations, \" Birkhauser, 2001.\n        .. [3] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Laplace Distribution.\"\n               From MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.\n               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/LaplaceDistribution.html\n        .. [4] Wikipedia, \"Laplace distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laplace_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution\n\n        >>> loc, scale = 0., 1.\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.laplace(loc, scale, 1000)\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 30, density=True)\n        >>> x = np.arange(-8., 8., .01)\n        >>> pdf = np.exp(-abs(x-loc)/scale)/(2.*scale)\n        >>> plt.plot(x, pdf)\n\n        Plot Gaussian for comparison:\n\n        >>> g = (1/(scale * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi)) *\n        ...      np.exp(-(x - loc)**2 / (2 * scale**2)))\n        >>> plt.plot(x,g)\n\n        ";

 2486:         """
 2487:         laplace(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None)
 2488: 
 2489:         Draw samples from the Laplace or double exponential distribution with
 2490:         specified location (or mean) and scale (decay).
 2491: 
 2492:         The Laplace distribution is similar to the Gaussian/normal distribution,
 2493:         but is sharper at the peak and has fatter tails. It represents the
 2494:         difference between two independent, identically distributed exponential
 2495:         random variables.
 2496: 
 2497:         Parameters
 2498:         ----------
 2499:         loc : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2500:             The position, :math:`\\mu`, of the distribution peak. Default is 0.
 2501:         scale : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2502:             :math:`\\lambda`, the exponential decay. Default is 1. Must be non-
 2503:             negative.
 2504:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2505:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2506:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2507:             a single value is returned if ``loc`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.
 2508:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(loc, scale).size`` samples are drawn.
 2509: 
 2510:         Returns
 2511:         -------
 2512:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2513:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Laplace distribution.
 2514: 
 2515:         Notes
 2516:         -----
 2517:         It has the probability density function
 2518: 
 2519:         .. math:: f(x; \\mu, \\lambda) = \\frac{1}{2\\lambda}
 2520:                                        \\exp\\left(-\\frac{|x - \\mu|}{\\lambda}\\right).
 2521: 
 2522:         The first law of Laplace, from 1774, states that the frequency
 2523:         of an error can be expressed as an exponential function of the
 2524:         absolute magnitude of the error, which leads to the Laplace
 2525:         distribution. For many problems in economics and health
 2526:         sciences, this distribution seems to model the data better
 2527:         than the standard Gaussian distribution.
 2528: 
 2529:         References
 2530:         ----------
 2531:         .. [1] Abramowitz, M. and Stegun, I. A. (Eds.). "Handbook of
 2532:                Mathematical Functions with Formulas, Graphs, and Mathematical
 2533:                Tables, 9th printing," New York: Dover, 1972.
 2534:         .. [2] Kotz, Samuel, et. al. "The Laplace Distribution and
 2535:                Generalizations, " Birkhauser, 2001.
 2536:         .. [3] Weisstein, Eric W. "Laplace Distribution."
 2537:                From MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.
 2538:                https://mathworld.wolfram.com/LaplaceDistribution.html
 2539:         .. [4] Wikipedia, "Laplace distribution",
 2540:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laplace_distribution
 2541: 
 2542:         Examples
 2543:         --------
 2544:         Draw samples from the distribution
 2545: 
 2546:         >>> loc, scale = 0., 1.
 2547:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.laplace(loc, scale, 1000)
 2548: 
 2549:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 2550:         the probability density function:
 2551: 
 2552:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2553:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 30, density=True)
 2554:         >>> x = np.arange(-8., 8., .01)
 2555:         >>> pdf = np.exp(-abs(x-loc)/scale)/(2.*scale)
 2556:         >>> plt.plot(x, pdf)
 2557: 
 2558:         Plot Gaussian for comparison:
 2559: 
 2560:         >>> g = (1/(scale * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi)) *
 2561:         ...      np.exp(-(x - loc)**2 / (2 * scale**2)))
 2562:         >>> plt.plot(x,g)
 2563:

+2570:     def gumbel(self, loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_77gumbel(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_76gumbel[] = "\n        gumbel(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Gumbel distribution.\n\n        Draw samples from a Gumbel distribution with specified location and\n        scale. For more information on the Gumbel distribution, see\n        Notes and References below.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        loc : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            The location of the mode of the distribution. Default is 0.\n        scale : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            The scale parameter of the distribution. Default is 1. Must be non-\n            negative.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``loc`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(loc, scale).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Gumbel distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.gumbel_l\n        scipy.stats.gumbel_r\n        scipy.stats.genextreme\n        weibull\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The Gumbel (or Smallest Extreme Value (SEV) or the Smallest Extreme\n        Value Type I) distribution is one of a class of Generalized Extreme\n        Value (GEV) distributions used in modeling extreme value problems.\n        The Gumbel is a special case of the Extreme Value Type I distribution\n        for maximums from distributions with \"exponential-like\" tails.\n\n        The probability density for the Gumbel distribution is\n\n        .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{e^{-(x - \\mu)/ \\beta}}{\\beta} e^{ -e^{-(x - \\mu)/\n                  \\beta}},\n\n        where :math:`\\mu` is the mode, a location parameter, and\n        :math:`\\beta` is the scale parameter.\n\n        The Gumbel"" (named for German mathematician Emil Julius Gumbel) was used\n        very early in the hydrology literature, for modeling the occurrence of\n        flood events. It is also used for modeling maximum wind speed and\n        rainfall rates. It is a \"fat-tailed\" distribution - the probability of\n        an event in the tail of the distribution is larger than if one used a\n        Gaussian, hence the surprisingly frequent occurrence of 100-year\n        floods. Floods were initially modeled as a Gaussian process, which\n        underestimated the frequency of extreme events.\n\n        It is one of a class of extreme value distributions, the Generalized\n        Extreme Value (GEV) distributions, which also includes the Weibull and\n        Frechet.\n\n        The function has a mean of :math:`\\mu + 0.57721\\beta` and a variance\n        of :math:`\\frac{\\pi^2}{6}\\beta^2`.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Gumbel, E. J., \"Statistics of Extremes,\"\n               New York: Columbia University Press, 1958.\n        .. [2] Reiss, R.-D. and Thomas, M., \"Statistical Analysis of Extreme\n               Values from Insurance, Finance, Hydrology and Other Fields,\"\n               Basel: Birkhauser Verlag, 2001.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> mu, beta = 0, 0.1 # location and scale\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.gumbel(mu, beta, 1000)\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 30, density=True)\n        >>> plt.plot(bins, (1/beta)*np.exp(-(bins - mu)/beta)\n        ...          * np.exp( -np.exp( -(bins - mu) /beta) ),\n        ...          linewidth=2, color='r')\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        Show how an extreme value distribution can arise from a Gaussian process\n        and compare to a Gaussian:\n\n        >>""> means = []\n        >>> maxima = []\n        >>> for i in range(0,1000) :\n        ...    a = randomgen.generator.normal(mu, beta, 1000)\n        ...    means.append(a.mean())\n        ...    maxima.append(a.max())\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(maxima, 30, density=True)\n        >>> beta = np.std(maxima) * np.sqrt(6) / np.pi\n        >>> mu = np.mean(maxima) - 0.57721*beta\n        >>> plt.plot(bins, (1/beta)*np.exp(-(bins - mu)/beta)\n        ...          * np.exp(-np.exp(-(bins - mu)/beta)),\n        ...          linewidth=2, color='r')\n        >>> plt.plot(bins, 1/(beta * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi))\n        ...          * np.exp(-(bins - mu)**2 / (2 * beta**2)),\n        ...          linewidth=2, color='g')\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  1: values[0] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 0);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  0: break;
        default: goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;
      }
    }
    __pyx_v_loc = values[0];
    __pyx_v_scale = values[1];
    __pyx_v_size = values[2];
  }
  goto __pyx_L4_argument_unpacking_done;
  __pyx_L5_argtuple_error:;
  __Pyx_RaiseArgtupleInvalid("gumbel", 0, 0, 3, PyTuple_GET_SIZE(__pyx_args)); __PYX_ERR(0, 2570, __pyx_L3_error)
  __pyx_L3_error:;

  __Pyx_RefNannyFinishContext();
  return NULL;

  __Pyx_RefNannyFinishContext();

 2571:         """
 2572:         gumbel(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None)
 2573: 
 2574:         Draw samples from a Gumbel distribution.
 2575: 
 2576:         Draw samples from a Gumbel distribution with specified location and
 2577:         scale. For more information on the Gumbel distribution, see
 2578:         Notes and References below.
 2579: 
 2580:         Parameters
 2581:         ----------
 2582:         loc : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2583:             The location of the mode of the distribution. Default is 0.
 2584:         scale : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2585:             The scale parameter of the distribution. Default is 1. Must be non-
 2586:             negative.
 2587:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2588:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2589:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2590:             a single value is returned if ``loc`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.
 2591:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(loc, scale).size`` samples are drawn.
 2592: 
 2593:         Returns
 2594:         -------
 2595:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2596:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Gumbel distribution.
 2597: 
 2598:         See Also
 2599:         --------
 2600:         scipy.stats.gumbel_l
 2601:         scipy.stats.gumbel_r
 2602:         scipy.stats.genextreme
 2603:         weibull
 2604: 
 2605:         Notes
 2606:         -----
 2607:         The Gumbel (or Smallest Extreme Value (SEV) or the Smallest Extreme
 2608:         Value Type I) distribution is one of a class of Generalized Extreme
 2609:         Value (GEV) distributions used in modeling extreme value problems.
 2610:         The Gumbel is a special case of the Extreme Value Type I distribution
 2611:         for maximums from distributions with "exponential-like" tails.
 2612: 
 2613:         The probability density for the Gumbel distribution is
 2614: 
 2615:         .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{e^{-(x - \\mu)/ \\beta}}{\\beta} e^{ -e^{-(x - \\mu)/
 2616:                   \\beta}},
 2617: 
 2618:         where :math:`\\mu` is the mode, a location parameter, and
 2619:         :math:`\\beta` is the scale parameter.
 2620: 
 2621:         The Gumbel (named for German mathematician Emil Julius Gumbel) was used
 2622:         very early in the hydrology literature, for modeling the occurrence of
 2623:         flood events. It is also used for modeling maximum wind speed and
 2624:         rainfall rates. It is a "fat-tailed" distribution - the probability of
 2625:         an event in the tail of the distribution is larger than if one used a
 2626:         Gaussian, hence the surprisingly frequent occurrence of 100-year
 2627:         floods. Floods were initially modeled as a Gaussian process, which
 2628:         underestimated the frequency of extreme events.
 2629: 
 2630:         It is one of a class of extreme value distributions, the Generalized
 2631:         Extreme Value (GEV) distributions, which also includes the Weibull and
 2632:         Frechet.
 2633: 
 2634:         The function has a mean of :math:`\\mu + 0.57721\\beta` and a variance
 2635:         of :math:`\\frac{\\pi^2}{6}\\beta^2`.
 2636: 
 2637:         References
 2638:         ----------
 2639:         .. [1] Gumbel, E. J., "Statistics of Extremes,"
 2640:                New York: Columbia University Press, 1958.
 2641:         .. [2] Reiss, R.-D. and Thomas, M., "Statistical Analysis of Extreme
 2642:                Values from Insurance, Finance, Hydrology and Other Fields,"
 2643:                Basel: Birkhauser Verlag, 2001.
 2644: 
 2645:         Examples
 2646:         --------
 2647:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 2648: 
 2649:         >>> mu, beta = 0, 0.1 # location and scale
 2650:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.gumbel(mu, beta, 1000)
 2651: 
 2652:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 2653:         the probability density function:
 2654: 
 2655:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2656:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 30, density=True)
 2657:         >>> plt.plot(bins, (1/beta)*np.exp(-(bins - mu)/beta)
 2658:         ...          * np.exp( -np.exp( -(bins - mu) /beta) ),
 2659:         ...          linewidth=2, color='r')
 2660:         >>> plt.show()
 2661: 
 2662:         Show how an extreme value distribution can arise from a Gaussian process
 2663:         and compare to a Gaussian:
 2664: 
 2665:         >>> means = []
 2666:         >>> maxima = []
 2667:         >>> for i in range(0,1000) :
 2668:         ...    a = randomgen.generator.normal(mu, beta, 1000)
 2669:         ...    means.append(a.mean())
 2670:         ...    maxima.append(a.max())
 2671:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(maxima, 30, density=True)
 2672:         >>> beta = np.std(maxima) * np.sqrt(6) / np.pi
 2673:         >>> mu = np.mean(maxima) - 0.57721*beta
 2674:         >>> plt.plot(bins, (1/beta)*np.exp(-(bins - mu)/beta)
 2675:         ...          * np.exp(-np.exp(-(bins - mu)/beta)),
 2676:         ...          linewidth=2, color='r')
 2677:         >>> plt.plot(bins, 1/(beta * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi))
 2678:         ...          * np.exp(-(bins - mu)**2 / (2 * beta**2)),
 2679:         ...          linewidth=2, color='g')
 2680:         >>> plt.show()
 2681: 
 2682:         """
+2683:         return cont(&random_gumbel, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 2,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/*  */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&random_gumbel), (&__pyx_v_self->_bitgen), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 2, __pyx_v_loc, __pyx_n_u_loc, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_v_scale, __pyx_n_u_scale, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NON_NEGATIVE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__11, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 2683, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 2684:                     loc, "loc", CONS_NONE,
 2685:                     scale, "scale", CONS_NON_NEGATIVE,
 2686:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE, None)
 2687: 
+2688:     def logistic(self, loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_79logistic(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_78logistic[] = "\n        logistic(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a logistic distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a logistic distribution with specified\n        parameters, loc (location or mean, also median), and scale (>0).\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        loc : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            Parameter of the distribution. Default is 0.\n        scale : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            Parameter of the distribution. Must be non-negative.\n            Default is 1.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``loc`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(loc, scale).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized logistic distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.logistic : probability density function, distribution or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density for the Logistic distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(x) = P(x) = \\frac{e^{-(x-\\mu)/s}}{s(1+e^{-(x-\\mu)/s})^2},\n\n        where :math:`\\mu` = location and :math:`s` = scale.\n\n        The Logistic distribution is used in Extreme Value problems where it\n        can act as a mixture of Gumbel distributions, in Epidemiology, and by\n        the World Chess Federation (FIDE) where it is used in the Elo ranking\n        system, assuming the performance of each player is a logistically\n        distributed random variable.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Reiss, R.-D. and Thomas M. (2001), \"Statistical Analysis of\n               Extreme Values, from Insurance, Finance, Hydrol""ogy and Other\n               Fields,\" Birkhauser Verlag, Basel, pp 132-133.\n        .. [2] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Logistic Distribution.\" From\n               MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.\n               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/LogisticDistribution.html\n        .. [3] Wikipedia, \"Logistic-distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> loc, scale = 10, 1\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.logistic(loc, scale, 10000)\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, bins=50)\n\n        #   plot against distribution\n\n        >>> def logist(x, loc, scale):\n        ...     return np.exp((loc-x)/scale)/(scale*(1+np.exp((loc-x)/scale))**2)\n        >>> lgst_val = logist(bins, loc, scale)\n        >>> plt.plot(bins, lgst_val * count.max() / lgst_val.max())\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 2689:         """
 2690:         logistic(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=None)
 2691: 
 2692:         Draw samples from a logistic distribution.
 2693: 
 2694:         Samples are drawn from a logistic distribution with specified
 2695:         parameters, loc (location or mean, also median), and scale (>0).
 2696: 
 2697:         Parameters
 2698:         ----------
 2699:         loc : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2700:             Parameter of the distribution. Default is 0.
 2701:         scale : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2702:             Parameter of the distribution. Must be non-negative.
 2703:             Default is 1.
 2704:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2705:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2706:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2707:             a single value is returned if ``loc`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.
 2708:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(loc, scale).size`` samples are drawn.
 2709: 
 2710:         Returns
 2711:         -------
 2712:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2713:             Drawn samples from the parameterized logistic distribution.
 2714: 
 2715:         See Also
 2716:         --------
 2717:         scipy.stats.logistic : probability density function, distribution or
 2718:             cumulative density function, etc.
 2719: 
 2720:         Notes
 2721:         -----
 2722:         The probability density for the Logistic distribution is
 2723: 
 2724:         .. math:: P(x) = P(x) = \\frac{e^{-(x-\\mu)/s}}{s(1+e^{-(x-\\mu)/s})^2},
 2725: 
 2726:         where :math:`\\mu` = location and :math:`s` = scale.
 2727: 
 2728:         The Logistic distribution is used in Extreme Value problems where it
 2729:         can act as a mixture of Gumbel distributions, in Epidemiology, and by
 2730:         the World Chess Federation (FIDE) where it is used in the Elo ranking
 2731:         system, assuming the performance of each player is a logistically
 2732:         distributed random variable.
 2733: 
 2734:         References
 2735:         ----------
 2736:         .. [1] Reiss, R.-D. and Thomas M. (2001), "Statistical Analysis of
 2737:                Extreme Values, from Insurance, Finance, Hydrology and Other
 2738:                Fields," Birkhauser Verlag, Basel, pp 132-133.
 2739:         .. [2] Weisstein, Eric W. "Logistic Distribution." From
 2740:                MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.
 2741:                https://mathworld.wolfram.com/LogisticDistribution.html
 2742:         .. [3] Wikipedia, "Logistic-distribution",
 2743:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_distribution
 2744: 
 2745:         Examples
 2746:         --------
 2747:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 2748: 
 2749:         >>> loc, scale = 10, 1
 2750:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.logistic(loc, scale, 10000)
 2751:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2752:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, bins=50)
 2753: 
 2754:         #   plot against distribution
 2755: 
 2756:         >>> def logist(x, loc, scale):
 2757:         ...     return np.exp((loc-x)/scale)/(scale*(1+np.exp((loc-x)/scale))**2)
 2758:         >>> lgst_val = logist(bins, loc, scale)
 2759:         >>> plt.plot(bins, lgst_val * count.max() / lgst_val.max())
 2760:         >>> plt.show()
 2761:

+2768:     def lognormal(self, mean=0.0, sigma=1.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_81lognormal(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_80lognormal[] = "\n        lognormal(mean=0.0, sigma=1.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a log-normal distribution.\n\n        Draw samples from a log-normal distribution with specified mean,\n        standard deviation, and array shape. Note that the mean and standard\n        deviation are not the values for the distribution itself, but of the\n        underlying normal distribution it is derived from.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        mean : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            Mean value of the underlying normal distribution. Default is 0.\n        sigma : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            Standard deviation of the underlying normal distribution. Must be\n            non-negative. Default is 1.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``mean`` and ``sigma`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(mean, sigma).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized log-normal distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.lognorm : probability density function, distribution,\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        A variable `x` has a log-normal distribution if `log(x)` is normally\n        distributed. The probability density function for the log-normal\n        distribution is:\n\n        .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{1}{\\sigma x \\sqrt{2\\pi}}\n                         e^{(-\\frac{(ln(x)-\\mu)^2}{2\\sigma^2})}\n\n        where :math:`\\mu` is the mean and :math:`\\sigma` is the standard\n        deviation of the normally distributed logarithm of the variable.\n        A log-normal distribution results if a random variable is the *product*\n       "" of a large number of independent, identically-distributed variables in\n        the same way that a normal distribution results if the variable is the\n        *sum* of a large number of independent, identically-distributed\n        variables.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Limpert, E., Stahel, W. A., and Abbt, M., \"Log-normal\n               Distributions across the Sciences: Keys and Clues,\"\n               BioScience, Vol. 51, No. 5, May, 2001.\n               https://stat.ethz.ch/~stahel/lognormal/bioscience.pdf\n        .. [2] Reiss, R.D. and Thomas, M., \"Statistical Analysis of Extreme\n               Values,\" Basel: Birkhauser Verlag, 2001, pp. 31-32.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> mu, sigma = 3., 1. # mean and standard deviation\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.lognormal(mu, sigma, 1000)\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 100, density=True, align='mid')\n\n        >>> x = np.linspace(min(bins), max(bins), 10000)\n        >>> pdf = (np.exp(-(np.log(x) - mu)**2 / (2 * sigma**2))\n        ...        / (x * sigma * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi)))\n\n        >>> plt.plot(x, pdf, linewidth=2, color='r')\n        >>> plt.axis('tight')\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        Demonstrate that taking the products of random samples from a uniform\n        distribution can be fit well by a log-normal probability density\n        function.\n\n        >>> # Generate a thousand samples: each is the product of 100 random\n        >>> # values, drawn from a normal distribution.\n        >>> b = []\n        >>> for i in range(1000):\n        ...    a = 10. + randomgen.generator.standard_normal(100)\n        ...    b.append(np.product(a))\n\n        >>> b = np.array(b) / np.min(b) # scale values to be positive\n        >>> count, b""ins, ignored = plt.hist(b, 100, density=True, align='mid')\n        >>> sigma = np.std(np.log(b))\n        >>> mu = np.mean(np.log(b))\n\n        >>> x = np.linspace(min(bins), max(bins), 10000)\n        >>> pdf = (np.exp(-(np.log(x) - mu)**2 / (2 * sigma**2))\n        ...        / (x * sigma * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi)))\n\n        >>> plt.plot(x, pdf, color='r', linewidth=2)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 2769:         """
 2770:         lognormal(mean=0.0, sigma=1.0, size=None)
 2771: 
 2772:         Draw samples from a log-normal distribution.
 2773: 
 2774:         Draw samples from a log-normal distribution with specified mean,
 2775:         standard deviation, and array shape. Note that the mean and standard
 2776:         deviation are not the values for the distribution itself, but of the
 2777:         underlying normal distribution it is derived from.
 2778: 
 2779:         Parameters
 2780:         ----------
 2781:         mean : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2782:             Mean value of the underlying normal distribution. Default is 0.
 2783:         sigma : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2784:             Standard deviation of the underlying normal distribution. Must be
 2785:             non-negative. Default is 1.
 2786:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2787:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2788:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2789:             a single value is returned if ``mean`` and ``sigma`` are both scalars.
 2790:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(mean, sigma).size`` samples are drawn.
 2791: 
 2792:         Returns
 2793:         -------
 2794:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2795:             Drawn samples from the parameterized log-normal distribution.
 2796: 
 2797:         See Also
 2798:         --------
 2799:         scipy.stats.lognorm : probability density function, distribution,
 2800:             cumulative density function, etc.
 2801: 
 2802:         Notes
 2803:         -----
 2804:         A variable `x` has a log-normal distribution if `log(x)` is normally
 2805:         distributed. The probability density function for the log-normal
 2806:         distribution is:
 2807: 
 2808:         .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{1}{\\sigma x \\sqrt{2\\pi}}
 2809:                          e^{(-\\frac{(ln(x)-\\mu)^2}{2\\sigma^2})}
 2810: 
 2811:         where :math:`\\mu` is the mean and :math:`\\sigma` is the standard
 2812:         deviation of the normally distributed logarithm of the variable.
 2813:         A log-normal distribution results if a random variable is the *product*
 2814:         of a large number of independent, identically-distributed variables in
 2815:         the same way that a normal distribution results if the variable is the
 2816:         *sum* of a large number of independent, identically-distributed
 2817:         variables.
 2818: 
 2819:         References
 2820:         ----------
 2821:         .. [1] Limpert, E., Stahel, W. A., and Abbt, M., "Log-normal
 2822:                Distributions across the Sciences: Keys and Clues,"
 2823:                BioScience, Vol. 51, No. 5, May, 2001.
 2824:                https://stat.ethz.ch/~stahel/lognormal/bioscience.pdf
 2825:         .. [2] Reiss, R.D. and Thomas, M., "Statistical Analysis of Extreme
 2826:                Values," Basel: Birkhauser Verlag, 2001, pp. 31-32.
 2827: 
 2828:         Examples
 2829:         --------
 2830:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 2831: 
 2832:         >>> mu, sigma = 3., 1. # mean and standard deviation
 2833:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.lognormal(mu, sigma, 1000)
 2834: 
 2835:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 2836:         the probability density function:
 2837: 
 2838:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 2839:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 100, density=True, align='mid')
 2840: 
 2841:         >>> x = np.linspace(min(bins), max(bins), 10000)
 2842:         >>> pdf = (np.exp(-(np.log(x) - mu)**2 / (2 * sigma**2))
 2843:         ...        / (x * sigma * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi)))
 2844: 
 2845:         >>> plt.plot(x, pdf, linewidth=2, color='r')
 2846:         >>> plt.axis('tight')
 2847:         >>> plt.show()
 2848: 
 2849:         Demonstrate that taking the products of random samples from a uniform
 2850:         distribution can be fit well by a log-normal probability density
 2851:         function.
 2852: 
 2853:         >>> # Generate a thousand samples: each is the product of 100 random
 2854:         >>> # values, drawn from a normal distribution.
 2855:         >>> b = []
 2856:         >>> for i in range(1000):
 2857:         ...    a = 10. + randomgen.generator.standard_normal(100)
 2858:         ...    b.append(np.product(a))
 2859: 
 2860:         >>> b = np.array(b) / np.min(b) # scale values to be positive
 2861:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(b, 100, density=True, align='mid')
 2862:         >>> sigma = np.std(np.log(b))
 2863:         >>> mu = np.mean(np.log(b))
 2864: 
 2865:         >>> x = np.linspace(min(bins), max(bins), 10000)
 2866:         >>> pdf = (np.exp(-(np.log(x) - mu)**2 / (2 * sigma**2))
 2867:         ...        / (x * sigma * np.sqrt(2 * np.pi)))
 2868: 
 2869:         >>> plt.plot(x, pdf, color='r', linewidth=2)
 2870:         >>> plt.show()
 2871: 
 2872:         """
+2873:         return cont(&random_lognormal, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 2,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/*  */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_cont((&random_lognormal), (&__pyx_v_self->_bitgen), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 2, __pyx_v_mean, __pyx_n_u_mean, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_v_sigma, __pyx_n_u_sigma, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NON_NEGATIVE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__11, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, Py_None); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 2873, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 2874:                     mean, "mean", CONS_NONE,
 2875:                     sigma, "sigma", CONS_NON_NEGATIVE,
 2876:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE, None)
 2877: 
+2878:     def rayleigh(self, scale=1.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_83rayleigh(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_82rayleigh[] = "\n        rayleigh(scale=1.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Rayleigh distribution.\n\n        The :math:`\\chi` and Weibull distributions are generalizations of the\n        Rayleigh.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        scale : float or array_like of floats, optional\n            Scale, also equals the mode. Must be non-negative. Default is 1.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``scale`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(scale).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Rayleigh distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density function for the Rayleigh distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(x;scale) = \\frac{x}{scale^2}e^{\\frac{-x^2}{2 \\cdotp scale^2}}\n\n        The Rayleigh distribution would arise, for example, if the East\n        and North components of the wind velocity had identical zero-mean\n        Gaussian distributions. Then the wind speed would have a Rayleigh\n        distribution.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Brighton Webs Ltd., \"Rayleigh Distribution,\"\n               https://web.archive.org/web/20090514091424/http://brighton-webs.co.uk:80/distributions/rayleigh.asp\n        .. [2] Wikipedia, \"Rayleigh distribution\"\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rayleigh_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw values from the distribution and plot the histogram\n\n        >>> from matplotlib.pyplot import hist\n        >>> values = hist(randomgen.generator.rayleigh(3, 100000), bins=200, density=True)\n\n        Wave heights tend to follow a Rayleigh distribution. If the mean wave\n        height is 1 meter, what fracti""on of waves are likely to be larger than 3\n        meters?\n\n        >>> meanvalue = 1\n        >>> modevalue = np.sqrt(2 / np.pi) * meanvalue\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.rayleigh(modevalue, 1000000)\n\n        The percentage of waves larger than 3 meters is:\n\n        >>> 100.*sum(s>3)/1000000.\n        0.087300000000000003 # random\n\n        ";

 2879:         """
 2880:         rayleigh(scale=1.0, size=None)
 2881: 
 2882:         Draw samples from a Rayleigh distribution.
 2883: 
 2884:         The :math:`\\chi` and Weibull distributions are generalizations of the
 2885:         Rayleigh.
 2886: 
 2887:         Parameters
 2888:         ----------
 2889:         scale : float or array_like of floats, optional
 2890:             Scale, also equals the mode. Must be non-negative. Default is 1.
 2891:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2892:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2893:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2894:             a single value is returned if ``scale`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 2895:             ``np.array(scale).size`` samples are drawn.
 2896: 
 2897:         Returns
 2898:         -------
 2899:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2900:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Rayleigh distribution.
 2901: 
 2902:         Notes
 2903:         -----
 2904:         The probability density function for the Rayleigh distribution is
 2905: 
 2906:         .. math:: P(x;scale) = \\frac{x}{scale^2}e^{\\frac{-x^2}{2 \\cdotp scale^2}}
 2907: 
 2908:         The Rayleigh distribution would arise, for example, if the East
 2909:         and North components of the wind velocity had identical zero-mean
 2910:         Gaussian distributions. Then the wind speed would have a Rayleigh
 2911:         distribution.
 2912: 
 2913:         References
 2914:         ----------
 2915:         .. [1] Brighton Webs Ltd., "Rayleigh Distribution,"
 2916:                https://web.archive.org/web/20090514091424/http://brighton-webs.co.uk:80/distributions/rayleigh.asp
 2917:         .. [2] Wikipedia, "Rayleigh distribution"
 2918:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rayleigh_distribution
 2919: 
 2920:         Examples
 2921:         --------
 2922:         Draw values from the distribution and plot the histogram
 2923: 
 2924:         >>> from matplotlib.pyplot import hist
 2925:         >>> values = hist(randomgen.generator.rayleigh(3, 100000), bins=200, density=True)
 2926: 
 2927:         Wave heights tend to follow a Rayleigh distribution. If the mean wave
 2928:         height is 1 meter, what fraction of waves are likely to be larger than 3
 2929:         meters?
 2930: 
 2931:         >>> meanvalue = 1
 2932:         >>> modevalue = np.sqrt(2 / np.pi) * meanvalue
 2933:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.rayleigh(modevalue, 1000000)
 2934: 
 2935:         The percentage of waves larger than 3 meters is:
 2936: 
 2937:         >>> 100.*sum(s>3)/1000000.
 2938:         0.087300000000000003 # random
 2939: 
 2940:         """
+2941:         return cont(&random_rayleigh, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 1,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);

 2945: 
+2946:     def wald(self, mean, scale, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_85wald(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_84wald[] = "\n        wald(mean, scale, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Wald, or inverse Gaussian, distribution.\n\n        As the scale approaches infinity, the distribution becomes more like a\n        Gaussian. Some references claim that the Wald is an inverse Gaussian\n        with mean equal to 1, but this is by no means universal.\n\n        The inverse Gaussian distribution was first studied in relationship to\n        Brownian motion. In 1956 M.C.K. Tweedie used the name inverse Gaussian\n        because there is an inverse relationship between the time to cover a\n        unit distance and distance covered in unit time.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        mean : float or array_like of floats\n            Distribution mean, must be > 0.\n        scale : float or array_like of floats\n            Scale parameter, must be > 0.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``mean`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(mean, scale).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Wald distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density function for the Wald distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(x;mean,scale) = \\sqrt{\\frac{scale}{2\\pi x^3}}e^\n                                    \\frac{-scale(x-mean)^2}{2\\cdotp mean^2x}\n\n        As noted above the inverse Gaussian distribution first arise\n        from attempts to model Brownian motion. It is also a\n        competitor to the Weibull for use in reliability modeling and\n        modeling stock returns and interest rate processes.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Brighton Webs Ltd., Wald Distribution,\n               https:""//web.archive.org/web/20090423014010/http://www.brighton-webs.co.uk:80/distributions/wald.asp\n        .. [2] Chhikara, Raj S., and Folks, J. Leroy, \"The Inverse Gaussian\n               Distribution: Theory : Methodology, and Applications\", CRC Press,\n               1988.\n        .. [3] Wikipedia, \"Inverse Gaussian distribution\"\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_Gaussian_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw values from the distribution and plot the histogram:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> h = plt.hist(randomgen.generator.wald(3, 2, 100000), bins=200, density=True)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 2947:         """
 2948:         wald(mean, scale, size=None)
 2949: 
 2950:         Draw samples from a Wald, or inverse Gaussian, distribution.
 2951: 
 2952:         As the scale approaches infinity, the distribution becomes more like a
 2953:         Gaussian. Some references claim that the Wald is an inverse Gaussian
 2954:         with mean equal to 1, but this is by no means universal.
 2955: 
 2956:         The inverse Gaussian distribution was first studied in relationship to
 2957:         Brownian motion. In 1956 M.C.K. Tweedie used the name inverse Gaussian
 2958:         because there is an inverse relationship between the time to cover a
 2959:         unit distance and distance covered in unit time.
 2960: 
 2961:         Parameters
 2962:         ----------
 2963:         mean : float or array_like of floats
 2964:             Distribution mean, must be > 0.
 2965:         scale : float or array_like of floats
 2966:             Scale parameter, must be > 0.
 2967:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 2968:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 2969:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 2970:             a single value is returned if ``mean`` and ``scale`` are both scalars.
 2971:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(mean, scale).size`` samples are drawn.
 2972: 
 2973:         Returns
 2974:         -------
 2975:         out : ndarray or scalar
 2976:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Wald distribution.
 2977: 
 2978:         Notes
 2979:         -----
 2980:         The probability density function for the Wald distribution is
 2981: 
 2982:         .. math:: P(x;mean,scale) = \\sqrt{\\frac{scale}{2\\pi x^3}}e^
 2983:                                     \\frac{-scale(x-mean)^2}{2\\cdotp mean^2x}
 2984: 
 2985:         As noted above the inverse Gaussian distribution first arise
 2986:         from attempts to model Brownian motion. It is also a
 2987:         competitor to the Weibull for use in reliability modeling and
 2988:         modeling stock returns and interest rate processes.
 2989: 
 2990:         References
 2991:         ----------
 2992:         .. [1] Brighton Webs Ltd., Wald Distribution,
 2993:                https://web.archive.org/web/20090423014010/http://www.brighton-webs.co.uk:80/distributions/wald.asp
 2994:         .. [2] Chhikara, Raj S., and Folks, J. Leroy, "The Inverse Gaussian
 2995:                Distribution: Theory : Methodology, and Applications", CRC Press,
 2996:                1988.
 2997:         .. [3] Wikipedia, "Inverse Gaussian distribution"
 2998:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_Gaussian_distribution
 2999: 
 3000:         Examples
 3001:         --------
 3002:         Draw values from the distribution and plot the histogram:
 3003: 
 3004:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 3005:         >>> h = plt.hist(randomgen.generator.wald(3, 2, 100000), bins=200, density=True)
 3006:         >>> plt.show()
 3007: 
 3008:         """

  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/*  */

 3013: 
+3014:     def triangular(self, left, mode, right, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_87triangular(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_86triangular[] = "\n        triangular(left, mode, right, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from the triangular distribution over the\n        interval ``[left, right]``.\n\n        The triangular distribution is a continuous probability\n        distribution with lower limit left, peak at mode, and upper\n        limit right. Unlike the other distributions, these parameters\n        directly define the shape of the pdf.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        left : float or array_like of floats\n            Lower limit.\n        mode : float or array_like of floats\n            The value where the peak of the distribution occurs.\n            The value must fulfill the condition ``left <= mode <= right``.\n        right : float or array_like of floats\n            Upper limit, must be larger than `left`.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``left``, ``mode``, and ``right``\n            are all scalars. Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(left, mode, right).size``\n            samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized triangular distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density function for the triangular distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(x;l, m, r) = \\begin{cases}\n                  \\frac{2(x-l)}{(r-l)(m-l)}& \\text{for $l \\leq x \\leq m$},\\\\\n                  \\frac{2(r-x)}{(r-l)(r-m)}& \\text{for $m \\leq x \\leq r$},\\\\\n                  0& \\text{otherwise}.\n                  \\end{cases}\n\n        The triangular distribution is often used in ill-defined\n        problems where the underlying distribution is not known, but\n        some knowledge of the limits and mode exists. Often it is used\n        in simulations.\n\n        Refere""nces\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Wikipedia, \"Triangular distribution\"\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangular_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw values from the distribution and plot the histogram:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> h = plt.hist(randomgen.generator.triangular(-3, 0, 8, 100000), bins=200,\n        ...              density=True)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 3015:         """
 3016:         triangular(left, mode, right, size=None)
 3017: 
 3018:         Draw samples from the triangular distribution over the
 3019:         interval ``[left, right]``.
 3020: 
 3021:         The triangular distribution is a continuous probability
 3022:         distribution with lower limit left, peak at mode, and upper
 3023:         limit right. Unlike the other distributions, these parameters
 3024:         directly define the shape of the pdf.
 3025: 
 3026:         Parameters
 3027:         ----------
 3028:         left : float or array_like of floats
 3029:             Lower limit.
 3030:         mode : float or array_like of floats
 3031:             The value where the peak of the distribution occurs.
 3032:             The value must fulfill the condition ``left <= mode <= right``.
 3033:         right : float or array_like of floats
 3034:             Upper limit, must be larger than `left`.
 3035:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3036:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3037:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 3038:             a single value is returned if ``left``, ``mode``, and ``right``
 3039:             are all scalars. Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(left, mode, right).size``
 3040:             samples are drawn.
 3041: 
 3042:         Returns
 3043:         -------
 3044:         out : ndarray or scalar
 3045:             Drawn samples from the parameterized triangular distribution.
 3046: 
 3047:         Notes
 3048:         -----
 3049:         The probability density function for the triangular distribution is
 3050: 
 3051:         .. math:: P(x;l, m, r) = \\begin{cases}
 3052:                   \\frac{2(x-l)}{(r-l)(m-l)}& \\text{for $l \\leq x \\leq m$},\\\\
 3053:                   \\frac{2(r-x)}{(r-l)(r-m)}& \\text{for $m \\leq x \\leq r$},\\\\
 3054:                   0& \\text{otherwise}.
 3055:                   \\end{cases}
 3056: 
 3057:         The triangular distribution is often used in ill-defined
 3058:         problems where the underlying distribution is not known, but
 3059:         some knowledge of the limits and mode exists. Often it is used
 3060:         in simulations.
 3061: 
 3062:         References
 3063:         ----------
 3064:         .. [1] Wikipedia, "Triangular distribution"
 3065:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangular_distribution
 3066: 
 3067:         Examples
 3068:         --------
 3069:         Draw values from the distribution and plot the histogram:
 3070: 
 3071:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 3072:         >>> h = plt.hist(randomgen.generator.triangular(-3, 0, 8, 100000), bins=200,
 3073:         ...              density=True)
 3074:         >>> plt.show()
 3075: 
 3076:         """
+3077:         cdef bint is_scalar = True
  __pyx_v_is_scalar = 1;

 3078:         cdef double fleft, fmode, fright
 3079:         cdef np.ndarray oleft, omode, oright
 3080: 
+3081:         oleft = <np.ndarray>np.PyArray_FROM_OTF(left, np.NPY_DOUBLE, api.NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED)

  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_1);
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_t_1;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_v_oleft = ((PyArrayObject *)__pyx_t_2);
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;

+3082:         omode = <np.ndarray>np.PyArray_FROM_OTF(mode, np.NPY_DOUBLE, api.NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED)
  __pyx_t_2 = PyArray_FROM_OTF(__pyx_v_mode, NPY_DOUBLE, NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3082, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
