 3113:     # Complicated, discrete distributions:
+3114:     def binomial(self, n, p, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_89binomial(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_88binomial[] = "\n        binomial(n, p, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a binomial distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a binomial distribution with specified\n        parameters, n trials and p probability of success where\n        n an integer >= 0 and p is in the interval [0,1]. (n may be\n        input as a float, but it is truncated to an integer in use)\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        n : int or array_like of ints\n            Parameter of the distribution, >= 0. Floats are also accepted,\n            but they will be truncated to integers.\n        p : float or array_like of floats\n            Parameter of the distribution, >= 0 and <=1.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``n`` and ``p`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(n, p).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized binomial distribution, where\n            each sample is equal to the number of successes over the n trials.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.binom : probability density function, distribution or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density for the binomial distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(N) = \\binom{n}{N}p^N(1-p)^{n-N},\n\n        where :math:`n` is the number of trials, :math:`p` is the probability\n        of success, and :math:`N` is the number of successes.\n\n        When estimating the standard error of a proportion in a population by\n        using a random sample, the normal distribution works well unless the\n        product p*n <=5, where p = population proportion estimate, and n =\n        number of samples, in which case the binomia""l distribution is used\n        instead. For example, a sample of 15 people shows 4 who are left\n        handed, and 11 who are right handed. Then p = 4/15 = 27%. 0.27*15 = 4,\n        so the binomial distribution should be used in this case.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Dalgaard, Peter, \"Introductory Statistics with R\",\n               Springer-Verlag, 2002.\n        .. [2] Glantz, Stanton A. \"Primer of Biostatistics.\", McGraw-Hill,\n               Fifth Edition, 2002.\n        .. [3] Lentner, Marvin, \"Elementary Applied Statistics\", Bogden\n               and Quigley, 1972.\n        .. [4] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Binomial Distribution.\" From MathWorld--A\n               Wolfram Web Resource.\n               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/BinomialDistribution.html\n        .. [5] Wikipedia, \"Binomial distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binomial_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> n, p = 10, .5  # number of trials, probability of each trial\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.binomial(n, p, 1000)\n        # result of flipping a coin 10 times, tested 1000 times.\n\n        A real world example. A company drills 9 wild-cat oil exploration\n        wells, each with an estimated probability of success of 0.1. All nine\n        wells fail. What is the probability of that happening?\n\n        Let's do 20,000 trials of the model, and count the number that\n        generate zero positive results.\n\n        >>> sum(randomgen.generator.binomial(9, 0.1, 20000) == 0)/20000.\n        # answer = 0.38885, or 38%.\n\n        ";

 3115:         """
 3116:         binomial(n, p, size=None)
 3117: 
 3118:         Draw samples from a binomial distribution.
 3119: 
 3120:         Samples are drawn from a binomial distribution with specified
 3121:         parameters, n trials and p probability of success where
 3122:         n an integer >= 0 and p is in the interval [0,1]. (n may be
 3123:         input as a float, but it is truncated to an integer in use)
 3124: 
 3125:         Parameters
 3126:         ----------
 3127:         n : int or array_like of ints
 3128:             Parameter of the distribution, >= 0. Floats are also accepted,
 3129:             but they will be truncated to integers.
 3130:         p : float or array_like of floats
 3131:             Parameter of the distribution, >= 0 and <=1.
 3132:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3133:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3134:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 3135:             a single value is returned if ``n`` and ``p`` are both scalars.
 3136:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(n, p).size`` samples are drawn.
 3137: 
 3138:         Returns
 3139:         -------
 3140:         out : ndarray or scalar
 3141:             Drawn samples from the parameterized binomial distribution, where
 3142:             each sample is equal to the number of successes over the n trials.
 3143: 
 3144:         See Also
 3145:         --------
 3146:         scipy.stats.binom : probability density function, distribution or
 3147:             cumulative density function, etc.
 3148: 
 3149:         Notes
 3150:         -----
 3151:         The probability density for the binomial distribution is
 3152: 
 3153:         .. math:: P(N) = \\binom{n}{N}p^N(1-p)^{n-N},
 3154: 
 3155:         where :math:`n` is the number of trials, :math:`p` is the probability
 3156:         of success, and :math:`N` is the number of successes.
 3157: 
 3158:         When estimating the standard error of a proportion in a population by
 3159:         using a random sample, the normal distribution works well unless the
 3160:         product p*n <=5, where p = population proportion estimate, and n =
 3161:         number of samples, in which case the binomial distribution is used
 3162:         instead. For example, a sample of 15 people shows 4 who are left
 3163:         handed, and 11 who are right handed. Then p = 4/15 = 27%. 0.27*15 = 4,
 3164:         so the binomial distribution should be used in this case.
 3165: 
 3166:         References
 3167:         ----------
 3168:         .. [1] Dalgaard, Peter, "Introductory Statistics with R",
 3169:                Springer-Verlag, 2002.
 3170:         .. [2] Glantz, Stanton A. "Primer of Biostatistics.", McGraw-Hill,
 3171:                Fifth Edition, 2002.
 3172:         .. [3] Lentner, Marvin, "Elementary Applied Statistics", Bogden
 3173:                and Quigley, 1972.
 3174:         .. [4] Weisstein, Eric W. "Binomial Distribution." From MathWorld--A
 3175:                Wolfram Web Resource.
 3176:                https://mathworld.wolfram.com/BinomialDistribution.html
 3177:         .. [5] Wikipedia, "Binomial distribution",
 3178:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binomial_distribution
 3179: 
 3180:         Examples
 3181:         --------
 3182:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 3183: 
 3184:         >>> n, p = 10, .5  # number of trials, probability of each trial
 3185:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.binomial(n, p, 1000)
 3186:         # result of flipping a coin 10 times, tested 1000 times.
 3187: 
 3188:         A real world example. A company drills 9 wild-cat oil exploration
 3189:         wells, each with an estimated probability of success of 0.1. All nine
 3190:         wells fail. What is the probability of that happening?
 3191: 
 3192:         Let's do 20,000 trials of the model, and count the number that
 3193:         generate zero positive results.
 3194: 
 3195:         >>> sum(randomgen.generator.binomial(9, 0.1, 20000) == 0)/20000.
 3196:         # answer = 0.38885, or 38%.
 3197: 
 3198:         """
 3199:

  __pyx_v__dp = 0.0;

 3257: 
+3258:     def negative_binomial(self, n, p, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_91negative_binomial(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_90negative_binomial[] = "\n        negative_binomial(n, p, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a negative binomial distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a negative binomial distribution with specified\n        parameters, `n` successes and `p` probability of success where `n`\n        is > 0 and `p` is in the interval [0, 1].\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        n : float or array_like of floats\n            Parameter of the distribution, > 0.\n        p : float or array_like of floats\n            Parameter of the distribution, >= 0 and <=1.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``n`` and ``p`` are both scalars.\n            Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(n, p).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized negative binomial distribution,\n            where each sample is equal to N, the number of failures that\n            occurred before a total of n successes was reached.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability mass function of the negative binomial distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(N;n,p) = \\frac{\\Gamma(N+n)}{N!\\Gamma(n)}p^{n}(1-p)^{N},\n\n        where :math:`n` is the number of successes, :math:`p` is the\n        probability of success, :math:`N+n` is the number of trials, and\n        :math:`\\Gamma` is the gamma function. When :math:`n` is an integer,\n        :math:`\\frac{\\Gamma(N+n)}{N!\\Gamma(n)} = \\binom{N+n-1}{N}`, which is\n        the more common form of this term in the the pmf. The negative\n        binomial distribution gives the probability of N failures given n\n        successes, with a success on the last trial.\n\n        If one throws a die repeatedly until the third time a \"1\" appears,\n        then the probability"" distribution of the number of non-\"1\"s that\n        appear before the third \"1\" is a negative binomial distribution.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Negative Binomial Distribution.\" From\n               MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.\n               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/NegativeBinomialDistribution.html\n        .. [2] Wikipedia, \"Negative binomial distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_binomial_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        A real world example. A company drills wild-cat oil\n        exploration wells, each with an estimated probability of\n        success of 0.1. What is the probability of having one success\n        for each successive well, that is what is the probability of a\n        single success after drilling 5 wells, after 6 wells, etc.?\n\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.negative_binomial(1, 0.1, 100000)\n        >>> for i in range(1, 11): # doctest: +SKIP\n        ...    probability = sum(s<i) / 100000.\n        ...    print(i, \"wells drilled, probability of one success =\", probability)\n\n        ";

 3259:         """
 3260:         negative_binomial(n, p, size=None)
 3261: 
 3262:         Draw samples from a negative binomial distribution.
 3263: 
 3264:         Samples are drawn from a negative binomial distribution with specified
 3265:         parameters, `n` successes and `p` probability of success where `n`
 3266:         is > 0 and `p` is in the interval [0, 1].
 3267: 
 3268:         Parameters
 3269:         ----------
 3270:         n : float or array_like of floats
 3271:             Parameter of the distribution, > 0.
 3272:         p : float or array_like of floats
 3273:             Parameter of the distribution, >= 0 and <=1.
 3274:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3275:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3276:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 3277:             a single value is returned if ``n`` and ``p`` are both scalars.
 3278:             Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(n, p).size`` samples are drawn.
 3279: 
 3280:         Returns
 3281:         -------
 3282:         out : ndarray or scalar
 3283:             Drawn samples from the parameterized negative binomial distribution,
 3284:             where each sample is equal to N, the number of failures that
 3285:             occurred before a total of n successes was reached.
 3286: 
 3287:         Notes
 3288:         -----
 3289:         The probability mass function of the negative binomial distribution is
 3290: 
 3291:         .. math:: P(N;n,p) = \\frac{\\Gamma(N+n)}{N!\\Gamma(n)}p^{n}(1-p)^{N},
 3292: 
 3293:         where :math:`n` is the number of successes, :math:`p` is the
 3294:         probability of success, :math:`N+n` is the number of trials, and
 3295:         :math:`\\Gamma` is the gamma function. When :math:`n` is an integer,
 3296:         :math:`\\frac{\\Gamma(N+n)}{N!\\Gamma(n)} = \\binom{N+n-1}{N}`, which is
 3297:         the more common form of this term in the the pmf. The negative
 3298:         binomial distribution gives the probability of N failures given n
 3299:         successes, with a success on the last trial.
 3300: 
 3301:         If one throws a die repeatedly until the third time a "1" appears,
 3302:         then the probability distribution of the number of non-"1"s that
 3303:         appear before the third "1" is a negative binomial distribution.
 3304: 
 3305:         References
 3306:         ----------
 3307:         .. [1] Weisstein, Eric W. "Negative Binomial Distribution." From
 3308:                MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.
 3309:                https://mathworld.wolfram.com/NegativeBinomialDistribution.html
 3310:         .. [2] Wikipedia, "Negative binomial distribution",
 3311:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_binomial_distribution
 3312: 
 3313:         Examples
 3314:         --------
 3315:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 3316: 
 3317:         A real world example. A company drills wild-cat oil
 3318:         exploration wells, each with an estimated probability of
 3319:         success of 0.1. What is the probability of having one success
 3320:         for each successive well, that is what is the probability of a
 3321:         single success after drilling 5 wells, after 6 wells, etc.?
 3322: 
 3323:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.negative_binomial(1, 0.1, 100000)
 3324:         >>> for i in range(1, 11): # doctest: +SKIP
 3325:         ...    probability = sum(s<i) / 100000.
 3326:         ...    print(i, "wells drilled, probability of one success =", probability)
 3327: 
 3328:         """
+3329:         return disc(&random_negative_binomial, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 2, 0,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/*  */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_disc((&random_negative_binomial), (&__pyx_v_self->_bitgen), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 2, 0, __pyx_v_n, __pyx_n_u_n, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_POSITIVE_NOT_NAN, __pyx_v_p, __pyx_n_u_p, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_BOUNDED_GT_0_1, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__11, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3329, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 3330:                     n, "n", CONS_POSITIVE_NOT_NAN,
 3331:                     p, "p", CONS_BOUNDED_GT_0_1,
 3332:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE)
 3333: 
+3334:     def poisson(self, lam=1.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_93poisson(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_92poisson[] = "\n        poisson(lam=1.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Poisson distribution.\n\n        The Poisson distribution is the limit of the binomial distribution\n        for large N.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        lam : float or array_like of floats\n            Expectation of interval, must be >= 0. A sequence of expectation\n            intervals must be broadcastable over the requested size.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``lam`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(lam).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Poisson distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The Poisson distribution\n\n        .. math:: f(k; \\lambda)=\\frac{\\lambda^k e^{-\\lambda}}{k!}\n\n        For events with an expected separation :math:`\\lambda` the Poisson\n        distribution :math:`f(k; \\lambda)` describes the probability of\n        :math:`k` events occurring within the observed\n        interval :math:`\\lambda`.\n\n        Because the output is limited to the range of the C int64 type, a\n        ValueError is raised when `lam` is within 10 sigma of the maximum\n        representable value.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Poisson Distribution.\"\n               From MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.\n               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/PoissonDistribution.html\n        .. [2] Wikipedia, \"Poisson distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poisson_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> import numpy as np\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.poisson(5, 10000)\n\n        Disp""lay histogram of the sample:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 14, density=True)\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        Draw each 100 values for lambda 100 and 500:\n\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.poisson(lam=(100., 500.), size=(100, 2))\n\n        ";

 3335:         """
 3336:         poisson(lam=1.0, size=None)
 3337: 
 3338:         Draw samples from a Poisson distribution.
 3339: 
 3340:         The Poisson distribution is the limit of the binomial distribution
 3341:         for large N.
 3342: 
 3343:         Parameters
 3344:         ----------
 3345:         lam : float or array_like of floats
 3346:             Expectation of interval, must be >= 0. A sequence of expectation
 3347:             intervals must be broadcastable over the requested size.
 3348:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3349:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3350:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 3351:             a single value is returned if ``lam`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 3352:             ``np.array(lam).size`` samples are drawn.
 3353: 
 3354:         Returns
 3355:         -------
 3356:         out : ndarray or scalar
 3357:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Poisson distribution.
 3358: 
 3359:         Notes
 3360:         -----
 3361:         The Poisson distribution
 3362: 
 3363:         .. math:: f(k; \\lambda)=\\frac{\\lambda^k e^{-\\lambda}}{k!}
 3364: 
 3365:         For events with an expected separation :math:`\\lambda` the Poisson
 3366:         distribution :math:`f(k; \\lambda)` describes the probability of
 3367:         :math:`k` events occurring within the observed
 3368:         interval :math:`\\lambda`.
 3369: 
 3370:         Because the output is limited to the range of the C int64 type, a
 3371:         ValueError is raised when `lam` is within 10 sigma of the maximum
 3372:         representable value.
 3373: 
 3374:         References
 3375:         ----------
 3376:         .. [1] Weisstein, Eric W. "Poisson Distribution."
 3377:                From MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.
 3378:                https://mathworld.wolfram.com/PoissonDistribution.html
 3379:         .. [2] Wikipedia, "Poisson distribution",
 3380:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poisson_distribution
 3381: 
 3382:         Examples
 3383:         --------
 3384:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 3385: 
 3386:         >>> import numpy as np
 3387:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.poisson(5, 10000)
 3388: 
 3389:         Display histogram of the sample:
 3390: 
 3391:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 3392:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s, 14, density=True)
 3393:         >>> plt.show()
 3394: 
 3395:         Draw each 100 values for lambda 100 and 500:
 3396: 
 3397:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.poisson(lam=(100., 500.), size=(100, 2))
 3398: 
 3399:         """
+3400:         return disc(&random_poisson, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 1, 0,

  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);

+3405:     def zipf(self, a, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_95zipf(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_94zipf[] = "\n        zipf(a, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Zipf distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a Zipf distribution with specified parameter\n        `a` > 1.\n\n        The Zipf distribution (also known as the zeta distribution) is a\n        continuous probability distribution that satisfies Zipf's law: the\n        frequency of an item is inversely proportional to its rank in a\n        frequency table.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        a : float or array_like of floats\n            Distribution parameter. Must be greater than 1.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized Zipf distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.zipf : probability density function, distribution, or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density for the Zipf distribution is\n\n        .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{x^{-a}}{\\zeta(a)},\n\n        where :math:`\\zeta` is the Riemann Zeta function.\n\n        It is named for the American linguist George Kingsley Zipf, who noted\n        that the frequency of any word in a sample of a language is inversely\n        proportional to its rank in the frequency table.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Zipf, G. K., \"Selected Studies of the Principle of Relative\n               Frequency in Language,\" Cambridge, MA: Harvard Univ. Press,\n               1932.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> a = 2. # parameter\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.zi""pf(a, 1000)\n\n        Display the histogram of the samples, along with\n        the probability density function:\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> from scipy import special  # doctest: +SKIP\n\n        Truncate s values at 50 so plot is interesting:\n\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s[s<50],\n        ...         50, density=True)\n        >>> x = np.arange(1., 50.)\n        >>> y = x**(-a) / special.zetac(a)  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.plot(x, y/max(y), linewidth=2, color='r')  # doctest: +SKIP\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 3406:         """
 3407:         zipf(a, size=None)
 3408: 
 3409:         Draw samples from a Zipf distribution.
 3410: 
 3411:         Samples are drawn from a Zipf distribution with specified parameter
 3412:         `a` > 1.
 3413: 
 3414:         The Zipf distribution (also known as the zeta distribution) is a
 3415:         continuous probability distribution that satisfies Zipf's law: the
 3416:         frequency of an item is inversely proportional to its rank in a
 3417:         frequency table.
 3418: 
 3419:         Parameters
 3420:         ----------
 3421:         a : float or array_like of floats
 3422:             Distribution parameter. Must be greater than 1.
 3423:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3424:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3425:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 3426:             a single value is returned if ``a`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 3427:             ``np.array(a).size`` samples are drawn.
 3428: 
 3429:         Returns
 3430:         -------
 3431:         out : ndarray or scalar
 3432:             Drawn samples from the parameterized Zipf distribution.
 3433: 
 3434:         See Also
 3435:         --------
 3436:         scipy.stats.zipf : probability density function, distribution, or
 3437:             cumulative density function, etc.
 3438: 
 3439:         Notes
 3440:         -----
 3441:         The probability density for the Zipf distribution is
 3442: 
 3443:         .. math:: p(x) = \\frac{x^{-a}}{\\zeta(a)},
 3444: 
 3445:         where :math:`\\zeta` is the Riemann Zeta function.
 3446: 
 3447:         It is named for the American linguist George Kingsley Zipf, who noted
 3448:         that the frequency of any word in a sample of a language is inversely
 3449:         proportional to its rank in the frequency table.
 3450: 
 3451:         References
 3452:         ----------
 3453:         .. [1] Zipf, G. K., "Selected Studies of the Principle of Relative
 3454:                Frequency in Language," Cambridge, MA: Harvard Univ. Press,
 3455:                1932.
 3456: 
 3457:         Examples
 3458:         --------
 3459:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 3460: 
 3461:         >>> a = 2. # parameter
 3462:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.zipf(a, 1000)
 3463: 
 3464:         Display the histogram of the samples, along with
 3465:         the probability density function:
 3466: 
 3467:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 3468:         >>> from scipy import special  # doctest: +SKIP
 3469: 
 3470:         Truncate s values at 50 so plot is interesting:
 3471: 
 3472:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s[s<50],
 3473:         ...         50, density=True)
 3474:         >>> x = np.arange(1., 50.)
 3475:         >>> y = x**(-a) / special.zetac(a)  # doctest: +SKIP
 3476:         >>> plt.plot(x, y/max(y), linewidth=2, color='r')  # doctest: +SKIP
 3477:         >>> plt.show()
 3478:

 3482:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE,

 3484: 
+3485:     def geometric(self, p, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_97geometric(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_96geometric[] = "\n        geometric(p, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from the geometric distribution.\n\n        Bernoulli trials are experiments with one of two outcomes:\n        success or failure (an example of such an experiment is flipping\n        a coin). The geometric distribution models the number of trials\n        that must be run in order to achieve success. It is therefore\n        supported on the positive integers, ``k = 1, 2, ...``.\n\n        The probability mass function of the geometric distribution is\n\n        .. math:: f(k) = (1 - p)^{k - 1} p\n\n        where `p` is the probability of success of an individual trial.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        p : float or array_like of floats\n            The probability of success of an individual trial.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``p`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(p).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized geometric distribution.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw ten thousand values from the geometric distribution,\n        with the probability of an individual success equal to 0.35:\n\n        >>> z = randomgen.generator.geometric(p=0.35, size=10000)\n\n        How many trials succeeded after a single run?\n\n        >>> (z == 1).sum() / 10000.\n        0.34889999999999999 #random\n\n        ";
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_97geometric(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds) {
  PyObject *__pyx_v_p = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_v_size = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_r = 0;
  __Pyx_RefNannyDeclarations
  __Pyx_RefNannySetupContext("geometric (wrapper)", 0);
  {
    static PyObject **__pyx_pyargnames[] = {&__pyx_n_s_p,&__pyx_n_s_size,0};
    PyObject* values[2] = {0,0};
    values[1] = ((PyObject *)Py_None);
    if (unlikely(__pyx_kwds)) {
      Py_ssize_t kw_args;
      const Py_ssize_t pos_args = PyTuple_GET_SIZE(__pyx_args);
      switch (pos_args) {
        case  2: values[1] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 1);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  1: values[0] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 0);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  0: break;
        default: goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;
      }

      switch (pos_args) {
        case  0:

        else goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;

          if (value) { values[1] = value; kw_args--; }

 3486:         """
 3487:         geometric(p, size=None)
 3488: 
 3489:         Draw samples from the geometric distribution.
 3490: 
 3491:         Bernoulli trials are experiments with one of two outcomes:
 3492:         success or failure (an example of such an experiment is flipping
 3493:         a coin). The geometric distribution models the number of trials
 3494:         that must be run in order to achieve success. It is therefore
 3495:         supported on the positive integers, ``k = 1, 2, ...``.
 3496: 
 3497:         The probability mass function of the geometric distribution is
 3498: 
 3499:         .. math:: f(k) = (1 - p)^{k - 1} p
 3500: 
 3501:         where `p` is the probability of success of an individual trial.
 3502: 
 3503:         Parameters
 3504:         ----------
 3505:         p : float or array_like of floats
 3506:             The probability of success of an individual trial.
 3507:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3508:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3509:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 3510:             a single value is returned if ``p`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 3511:             ``np.array(p).size`` samples are drawn.
 3512: 
 3513:         Returns
 3514:         -------
 3515:         out : ndarray or scalar
 3516:             Drawn samples from the parameterized geometric distribution.
 3517: 
 3518:         Examples
 3519:         --------
 3520:         Draw ten thousand values from the geometric distribution,
 3521:         with the probability of an individual success equal to 0.35:
 3522: 
 3523:         >>> z = randomgen.generator.geometric(p=0.35, size=10000)
 3524: 
 3525:         How many trials succeeded after a single run?
 3526: 
 3527:         >>> (z == 1).sum() / 10000.
 3528:         0.34889999999999999 #random
 3529: 
 3530:         """
+3531:         return disc(&random_geometric, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 1, 0,
  __Pyx_XDECREF(__pyx_r);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_v_self->lock;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
/*  */
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_f_9randomgen_6common_disc((&random_geometric), (&__pyx_v_self->_bitgen), __pyx_v_size, __pyx_t_1, 1, 0, __pyx_v_p, __pyx_n_u_p, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_BOUNDED_GT_0_1, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__11, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE, __pyx_float_0_0, __pyx_kp_u__11, __pyx_e_9randomgen_6common_CONS_NONE); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3531, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_r = __pyx_t_2;
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  goto __pyx_L0;

 3532:                     p, "p", CONS_BOUNDED_GT_0_1,
 3533:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE,
 3534:                     0.0, "", CONS_NONE)
 3535: 
+3536:     def hypergeometric(self, ngood, nbad, nsample, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_99hypergeometric(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_98hypergeometric[] = "\n        hypergeometric(ngood, nbad, nsample, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a Hypergeometric distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a hypergeometric distribution with specified\n        parameters, `ngood` (ways to make a good selection), `nbad` (ways to make\n        a bad selection), and `nsample` (number of items sampled, which is less\n        than or equal to the sum ``ngood + nbad``).\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        ngood : int or array_like of ints\n            Number of ways to make a good selection. Must be nonnegative.\n        nbad : int or array_like of ints\n            Number of ways to make a bad selection. Must be nonnegative.\n        nsample : int or array_like of ints\n            Number of items sampled. Must be nonnegative and less than\n            ``ngood + nbad``.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if `ngood`, `nbad`, and `nsample`\n            are all scalars. Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(ngood, nbad, nsample).size``\n            samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized hypergeometric distribution. Each\n            sample is the number of good items within a randomly selected subset of\n            size `nsample` taken from a set of `ngood` good items and `nbad` bad items.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.hypergeom : probability density function, distribution or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability density for the Hypergeometric distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(x) = \\frac{\\binom{g}{x}\\binom{b}{n-x}}{\\binom{g+b}{n}},\n\n        where :math:`0 \\le x \\le n` and :math:`n-b \\le x \\le g`\n\n        for P(x) th""e probability of ``x`` good results in the drawn sample,\n        g = `ngood`, b = `nbad`, and n = `nsample`.\n\n        Consider an urn with black and white marbles in it, `ngood` of them\n        are black and `nbad` are white. If you draw `nsample` balls without\n        replacement, then the hypergeometric distribution describes the\n        distribution of black balls in the drawn sample.\n\n        Note that this distribution is very similar to the binomial\n        distribution, except that in this case, samples are drawn without\n        replacement, whereas in the Binomial case samples are drawn with\n        replacement (or the sample space is infinite). As the sample space\n        becomes large, this distribution approaches the binomial.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Lentner, Marvin, \"Elementary Applied Statistics\", Bogden\n               and Quigley, 1972.\n        .. [2] Weisstein, Eric W. \"Hypergeometric Distribution.\" From\n               MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.\n               https://mathworld.wolfram.com/HypergeometricDistribution.html\n        .. [3] Wikipedia, \"Hypergeometric distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypergeometric_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> ngood, nbad, nsamp = 100, 2, 10\n        # number of good, number of bad, and number of samples\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.hypergeometric(ngood, nbad, nsamp, 1000)\n        >>> from matplotlib.pyplot import hist\n        >>> hist(s)\n        #   note that it is very unlikely to grab both bad items\n\n        Suppose you have an urn with 15 white and 15 black marbles.\n        If you pull 15 marbles at random, how likely is it that\n        12 or more of them are one color?\n\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.hypergeometric(15, 15, 15, 100000)\n        >>> sum(s>=12)/100000. + sum(s<=3)/100000.\n        #   answer = 0.003 ... pretty u""nlikely!\n\n        ";

 3537:         """
 3538:         hypergeometric(ngood, nbad, nsample, size=None)
 3539: 
 3540:         Draw samples from a Hypergeometric distribution.
 3541: 
 3542:         Samples are drawn from a hypergeometric distribution with specified
 3543:         parameters, `ngood` (ways to make a good selection), `nbad` (ways to make
 3544:         a bad selection), and `nsample` (number of items sampled, which is less
 3545:         than or equal to the sum ``ngood + nbad``).
 3546: 
 3547:         Parameters
 3548:         ----------
 3549:         ngood : int or array_like of ints
 3550:             Number of ways to make a good selection. Must be nonnegative.
 3551:         nbad : int or array_like of ints
 3552:             Number of ways to make a bad selection. Must be nonnegative.
 3553:         nsample : int or array_like of ints
 3554:             Number of items sampled. Must be nonnegative and less than
 3555:             ``ngood + nbad``.
 3556:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3557:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3558:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 3559:             a single value is returned if `ngood`, `nbad`, and `nsample`
 3560:             are all scalars. Otherwise, ``np.broadcast(ngood, nbad, nsample).size``
 3561:             samples are drawn.
 3562: 
 3563:         Returns
 3564:         -------
 3565:         out : ndarray or scalar
 3566:             Drawn samples from the parameterized hypergeometric distribution. Each
 3567:             sample is the number of good items within a randomly selected subset of
 3568:             size `nsample` taken from a set of `ngood` good items and `nbad` bad items.
 3569: 
 3570:         See Also
 3571:         --------
 3572:         scipy.stats.hypergeom : probability density function, distribution or
 3573:             cumulative density function, etc.
 3574: 
 3575:         Notes
 3576:         -----
 3577:         The probability density for the Hypergeometric distribution is
 3578: 
 3579:         .. math:: P(x) = \\frac{\\binom{g}{x}\\binom{b}{n-x}}{\\binom{g+b}{n}},
 3580: 
 3581:         where :math:`0 \\le x \\le n` and :math:`n-b \\le x \\le g`
 3582: 
 3583:         for P(x) the probability of ``x`` good results in the drawn sample,
 3584:         g = `ngood`, b = `nbad`, and n = `nsample`.
 3585: 
 3586:         Consider an urn with black and white marbles in it, `ngood` of them
 3587:         are black and `nbad` are white. If you draw `nsample` balls without
 3588:         replacement, then the hypergeometric distribution describes the
 3589:         distribution of black balls in the drawn sample.
 3590: 
 3591:         Note that this distribution is very similar to the binomial
 3592:         distribution, except that in this case, samples are drawn without
 3593:         replacement, whereas in the Binomial case samples are drawn with
 3594:         replacement (or the sample space is infinite). As the sample space
 3595:         becomes large, this distribution approaches the binomial.
 3596: 
 3597:         References
 3598:         ----------
 3599:         .. [1] Lentner, Marvin, "Elementary Applied Statistics", Bogden
 3600:                and Quigley, 1972.
 3601:         .. [2] Weisstein, Eric W. "Hypergeometric Distribution." From
 3602:                MathWorld--A Wolfram Web Resource.
 3603:                https://mathworld.wolfram.com/HypergeometricDistribution.html
 3604:         .. [3] Wikipedia, "Hypergeometric distribution",
 3605:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypergeometric_distribution
 3606: 
 3607:         Examples
 3608:         --------
 3609:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 3610: 
 3611:         >>> ngood, nbad, nsamp = 100, 2, 10
 3612:         # number of good, number of bad, and number of samples
 3613:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.hypergeometric(ngood, nbad, nsamp, 1000)
 3614:         >>> from matplotlib.pyplot import hist
 3615:         >>> hist(s)
 3616:         #   note that it is very unlikely to grab both bad items
 3617: 
 3618:         Suppose you have an urn with 15 white and 15 black marbles.
 3619:         If you pull 15 marbles at random, how likely is it that
 3620:         12 or more of them are one color?
 3621: 
 3622:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.hypergeometric(15, 15, 15, 100000)
 3623:         >>> sum(s>=12)/100000. + sum(s<=3)/100000.
 3624:         #   answer = 0.003 ... pretty unlikely!
 3625: 
 3626:         """
 3627:         DEF HYPERGEOM_MAX = 10**9
+3628:         cdef bint is_scalar = True
  __pyx_v_is_scalar = 1;

 3629:         cdef np.ndarray ongood, onbad, onsample
 3630:         cdef int64_t lngood, lnbad, lnsample
 3631: 
+3632:         ongood = <np.ndarray>np.PyArray_FROM_OTF(ngood, np.NPY_INT64, api.NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED)
  __pyx_t_1 = PyArray_FROM_OTF(__pyx_v_ngood, NPY_INT64, NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_1)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3632, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_1);
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_t_1;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_v_ongood = ((PyArrayObject *)__pyx_t_2);
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;

+3633:         onbad = <np.ndarray>np.PyArray_FROM_OTF(nbad, np.NPY_INT64, api.NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED)
  __pyx_t_2 = PyArray_FROM_OTF(__pyx_v_nbad, NPY_INT64, NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3633, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __pyx_t_1 = __pyx_t_2;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_1);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_2); __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  __pyx_v_onbad = ((PyArrayObject *)__pyx_t_1);
  __pyx_t_1 = 0;

+3634:         onsample = <np.ndarray>np.PyArray_FROM_OTF(nsample, np.NPY_INT64, api.NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED)
  __pyx_t_1 = PyArray_FROM_OTF(__pyx_v_nsample, NPY_INT64, NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_1)) __PYX_ERR(0, 3634, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_1);
  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_t_1;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_v_onsample = ((PyArrayObject *)__pyx_t_2);
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;

 3635: 
+3636:         if np.PyArray_NDIM(ongood) == np.PyArray_NDIM(onbad) == np.PyArray_NDIM(onsample) == 0:
  __pyx_t_3 = PyArray_NDIM(__pyx_v_onbad);
  __pyx_t_4 = (PyArray_NDIM(__pyx_v_ongood) == __pyx_t_3);
  if (__pyx_t_4) {
    __pyx_t_5 = PyArray_NDIM(__pyx_v_onsample);
    __pyx_t_4 = (__pyx_t_3 == __pyx_t_5);
    if (__pyx_t_4) {
      __pyx_t_4 = (__pyx_t_5 == 0);
    }
  }
  __pyx_t_6 = (__pyx_t_4 != 0);
  if (__pyx_t_6) {
/*  */
  }

+3662:     def logseries(self, p, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_101logseries(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_100logseries[] = "\n        logseries(p, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a logarithmic series distribution.\n\n        Samples are drawn from a log series distribution with specified\n        shape parameter, 0 < ``p`` < 1.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        p : float or array_like of floats\n            Shape parameter for the distribution. Must be in the range (0, 1).\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``p`` is a scalar. Otherwise,\n            ``np.array(p).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized logarithmic series distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        scipy.stats.logser : probability density function, distribution or\n            cumulative density function, etc.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The probability mass function for the Log Series distribution is\n\n        .. math:: P(k) = \\frac{-p^k}{k \\ln(1-p)},\n\n        where p = probability.\n\n        The log series distribution is frequently used to represent species\n        richness and occurrence, first proposed by Fisher, Corbet, and\n        Williams in 1943 [2]. It may also be used to model the numbers of\n        occupants seen in cars [3].\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Buzas, Martin A.; Culver, Stephen J.,  Understanding regional\n               species diversity through the log series distribution of\n               occurrences: BIODIVERSITY RESEARCH Diversity & Distributions,\n               Volume 5, Number 5, September 1999 , pp. 187-195(9).\n        .. [2] Fisher, R.A,, A.S. Corbet, and C.B. Williams. 1943. The\n               relation between the number of species and the number of\n               individuals in a random"" sample of an animal population.\n               Journal of Animal Ecology, 12:42-58.\n        .. [3] D. J. Hand, F. Daly, D. Lunn, E. Ostrowski, A Handbook of Small\n               Data Sets, CRC Press, 1994.\n        .. [4] Wikipedia, \"Logarithmic distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logarithmic_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> a = .6\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.logseries(a, 10000)\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s)\n\n        #   plot against distribution\n\n        >>> def logseries(k, p):\n        ...     return -p**k/(k*np.log(1-p))\n        >>> plt.plot(bins, logseries(bins, a) * count.max()/\n        ...          logseries(bins, a).max(), 'r')\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        ";

 3663:         """
 3664:         logseries(p, size=None)
 3665: 
 3666:         Draw samples from a logarithmic series distribution.
 3667: 
 3668:         Samples are drawn from a log series distribution with specified
 3669:         shape parameter, 0 < ``p`` < 1.
 3670: 
 3671:         Parameters
 3672:         ----------
 3673:         p : float or array_like of floats
 3674:             Shape parameter for the distribution. Must be in the range (0, 1).
 3675:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3676:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3677:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 3678:             a single value is returned if ``p`` is a scalar. Otherwise,
 3679:             ``np.array(p).size`` samples are drawn.
 3680: 
 3681:         Returns
 3682:         -------
 3683:         out : ndarray or scalar
 3684:             Drawn samples from the parameterized logarithmic series distribution.
 3685: 
 3686:         See Also
 3687:         --------
 3688:         scipy.stats.logser : probability density function, distribution or
 3689:             cumulative density function, etc.
 3690: 
 3691:         Notes
 3692:         -----
 3693:         The probability mass function for the Log Series distribution is
 3694: 
 3695:         .. math:: P(k) = \\frac{-p^k}{k \\ln(1-p)},
 3696: 
 3697:         where p = probability.
 3698: 
 3699:         The log series distribution is frequently used to represent species
 3700:         richness and occurrence, first proposed by Fisher, Corbet, and
 3701:         Williams in 1943 [2]. It may also be used to model the numbers of
 3702:         occupants seen in cars [3].
 3703: 
 3704:         References
 3705:         ----------
 3706:         .. [1] Buzas, Martin A.; Culver, Stephen J.,  Understanding regional
 3707:                species diversity through the log series distribution of
 3708:                occurrences: BIODIVERSITY RESEARCH Diversity & Distributions,
 3709:                Volume 5, Number 5, September 1999 , pp. 187-195(9).
 3710:         .. [2] Fisher, R.A,, A.S. Corbet, and C.B. Williams. 1943. The
 3711:                relation between the number of species and the number of
 3712:                individuals in a random sample of an animal population.
 3713:                Journal of Animal Ecology, 12:42-58.
 3714:         .. [3] D. J. Hand, F. Daly, D. Lunn, E. Ostrowski, A Handbook of Small
 3715:                Data Sets, CRC Press, 1994.
 3716:         .. [4] Wikipedia, "Logarithmic distribution",
 3717:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logarithmic_distribution
 3718: 
 3719:         Examples
 3720:         --------
 3721:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 3722: 
 3723:         >>> a = .6
 3724:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.logseries(a, 10000)
 3725:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 3726:         >>> count, bins, ignored = plt.hist(s)
 3727: 
 3728:         #   plot against distribution
 3729: 
 3730:         >>> def logseries(k, p):
 3731:         ...     return -p**k/(k*np.log(1-p))
 3732:         >>> plt.plot(bins, logseries(bins, a) * count.max()/
 3733:         ...          logseries(bins, a).max(), 'r')
 3734:         >>> plt.show()
 3735: 
 3736:         """
+3737:         return disc(&random_logseries, &self._bitgen, size, self.lock, 1, 0,

 3742:     # Multivariate distributions:
+3743:     def multivariate_normal(self, mean, cov, size=None, check_valid="warn",
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_103multivariate_normal(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_102multivariate_normal[] = "\n        multivariate_normal(mean, cov, size=None, check_valid='warn', tol=1e-8, *, method='svd')\n\n        Draw random samples from a multivariate normal distribution.\n\n        The multivariate normal, multinormal or Gaussian distribution is a\n        generalization of the one-dimensional normal distribution to higher\n        dimensions. Such a distribution is specified by its mean and\n        covariance matrix. These parameters are analogous to the mean\n        (average or \"center\") and variance (standard deviation, or \"width,\"\n        squared) of the one-dimensional normal distribution.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        mean : array_like\n            Mean of the distribution. Must have shape (m1, m2, ..., mk, N) where\n            (m1, m2, ..., mk) would broadcast with (c1, c2, ..., cj).\n        cov : array_like\n            Covariance matrix of the distribution. It must be symmetric and\n            positive-semidefinite for proper sampling. Must have shape\n            (c1, c2, ..., cj, N, N) where (c1, c2, ..., cj) would broadcast\n            with (m1, m2, ..., mk).\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Given a shape of, for example, ``(m,n,k)``, ``m*n*k`` samples are\n            generated, and packed in an `m`-by-`n`-by-`k` arrangement.  Because\n            each sample is `N`-dimensional, the output shape is ``(m,n,k,N)``.\n            If no shape is specified, a single (`N`-D) sample is returned.\n        check_valid : { 'warn', 'raise', 'ignore' }, optional\n            Behavior when the covariance matrix is not positive semidefinite.\n        tol : float, optional\n            Tolerance when checking the singular values in covariance matrix.\n            cov is cast to double before the check.\n        method : { 'svd', 'eigh', 'cholesky'}, optional\n            The cov input is used to compute a factor matrix A such that\n            ``A @ A.T = cov``. This argument is used to select the method\n    ""        used to compute the factor matrix A. The default method 'svd' is\n            the slowest, while 'cholesky' is the fastest but less robust than\n            the slowest method. The method `eigh` uses eigen decomposition to\n            compute A and is faster than svd but slower than cholesky.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray\n            The drawn samples, of shape determined by broadcasting the\n            leading dimensions of mean and cov with size, if not None.\n            The final dimension is always N.\n\n            In other words, each entry ``out[i,j,...,:]`` is an N-dimensional\n            value drawn from the distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The mean is a coordinate in N-dimensional space, which represents the\n        location where samples are most likely to be generated. This is\n        analogous to the peak of the bell curve for the one-dimensional or\n        univariate normal distribution.\n\n        Covariance indicates the level to which two variables vary together.\n        From the multivariate normal distribution, we draw N-dimensional\n        samples, :math:`X = [x_1, x_2, ... x_N]`. The covariance matrix\n        element :math:`C_{ij}` is the covariance of :math:`x_i` and :math:`x_j`.\n        The element :math:`C_{ii}` is the variance of :math:`x_i` (i.e. its\n        \"spread\").\n\n        Instead of specifying the full covariance matrix, popular\n        approximations include:\n\n          - Spherical covariance (`cov` is a multiple of the identity matrix)\n          - Diagonal covariance (`cov` has non-negative elements, and only on\n            the diagonal)\n\n        This geometrical property can be seen in two dimensions by plotting\n        generated data-points:\n\n        >>> mean = [0, 0]\n        >>> cov = [[1, 0], [0, 100]]  # diagonal covariance\n\n        Diagonal covariance means that points are oriented along x or y-axis:\n\n        >>> from randomgen import Ge""nerator\n        >>> rg = Generator()\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> x, y = rg.multivariate_normal(mean, cov, 5000).T\n        >>> plt.plot(x, y, 'x')\n        >>> plt.axis('equal')\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        Note that the covariance matrix must be positive semidefinite (a.k.a.\n        nonnegative-definite). Otherwise, the behavior of this method is\n        undefined and backwards compatibility is not guaranteed.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Papoulis, A., \"Probability, Random Variables, and Stochastic\n               Processes,\" 3rd ed., New York: McGraw-Hill, 1991.\n        .. [2] Duda, R. O., Hart, P. E., and Stork, D. G., \"Pattern\n               Classification,\" 2nd ed., New York: Wiley, 2001.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        >>> from randomgen import Generator\n        >>> rg = Generator()\n        >>> mean = (1, 2)\n        >>> cov = [[1, 0], [0, 1]]\n        >>> x = rg.multivariate_normal(mean, cov, (3, 3))\n        >>> x.shape\n        (3, 3, 2)\n\n        The following is probably true, given that 0.6 is roughly twice the\n        standard deviation:\n\n        >>> list((x[0,0,:] - mean) < 0.6)\n        [True, True] # random\n\n        ";
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_103multivariate_normal(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds) {
  PyObject *__pyx_v_mean = 0;

/*  */
struct __pyx_obj_9randomgen_9generator___pyx_scope_struct__multivariate_normal {
  PyObject_HEAD
  PyObject *__pyx_v_tol;
};


 3744:                             tol=1e-8, *, method="svd"):
 3745:         """
 3746:         multivariate_normal(mean, cov, size=None, check_valid='warn', tol=1e-8, *, method='svd')
 3747: 
 3748:         Draw random samples from a multivariate normal distribution.
 3749: 
 3750:         The multivariate normal, multinormal or Gaussian distribution is a
 3751:         generalization of the one-dimensional normal distribution to higher
 3752:         dimensions. Such a distribution is specified by its mean and
 3753:         covariance matrix. These parameters are analogous to the mean
 3754:         (average or "center") and variance (standard deviation, or "width,"
 3755:         squared) of the one-dimensional normal distribution.
 3756: 
 3757:         Parameters
 3758:         ----------
 3759:         mean : array_like
 3760:             Mean of the distribution. Must have shape (m1, m2, ..., mk, N) where
 3761:             (m1, m2, ..., mk) would broadcast with (c1, c2, ..., cj).
 3762:         cov : array_like
 3763:             Covariance matrix of the distribution. It must be symmetric and
 3764:             positive-semidefinite for proper sampling. Must have shape
 3765:             (c1, c2, ..., cj, N, N) where (c1, c2, ..., cj) would broadcast
 3766:             with (m1, m2, ..., mk).
 3767:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3768:             Given a shape of, for example, ``(m,n,k)``, ``m*n*k`` samples are
 3769:             generated, and packed in an `m`-by-`n`-by-`k` arrangement.  Because
 3770:             each sample is `N`-dimensional, the output shape is ``(m,n,k,N)``.
 3771:             If no shape is specified, a single (`N`-D) sample is returned.
 3772:         check_valid : { 'warn', 'raise', 'ignore' }, optional
 3773:             Behavior when the covariance matrix is not positive semidefinite.
 3774:         tol : float, optional
 3775:             Tolerance when checking the singular values in covariance matrix.
 3776:             cov is cast to double before the check.
 3777:         method : { 'svd', 'eigh', 'cholesky'}, optional
 3778:             The cov input is used to compute a factor matrix A such that
 3779:             ``A @ A.T = cov``. This argument is used to select the method
 3780:             used to compute the factor matrix A. The default method 'svd' is
 3781:             the slowest, while 'cholesky' is the fastest but less robust than
 3782:             the slowest method. The method `eigh` uses eigen decomposition to
 3783:             compute A and is faster than svd but slower than cholesky.
 3784: 
 3785:         Returns
 3786:         -------
 3787:         out : ndarray
 3788:             The drawn samples, of shape determined by broadcasting the
 3789:             leading dimensions of mean and cov with size, if not None.
 3790:             The final dimension is always N.
 3791: 
 3792:             In other words, each entry ``out[i,j,...,:]`` is an N-dimensional
 3793:             value drawn from the distribution.
 3794: 
 3795:         Notes
 3796:         -----
 3797:         The mean is a coordinate in N-dimensional space, which represents the
 3798:         location where samples are most likely to be generated. This is
 3799:         analogous to the peak of the bell curve for the one-dimensional or
 3800:         univariate normal distribution.
 3801: 
 3802:         Covariance indicates the level to which two variables vary together.
 3803:         From the multivariate normal distribution, we draw N-dimensional
 3804:         samples, :math:`X = [x_1, x_2, ... x_N]`. The covariance matrix
 3805:         element :math:`C_{ij}` is the covariance of :math:`x_i` and :math:`x_j`.
 3806:         The element :math:`C_{ii}` is the variance of :math:`x_i` (i.e. its
 3807:         "spread").
 3808: 
 3809:         Instead of specifying the full covariance matrix, popular
 3810:         approximations include:
 3811: 
 3812:           - Spherical covariance (`cov` is a multiple of the identity matrix)
 3813:           - Diagonal covariance (`cov` has non-negative elements, and only on
 3814:             the diagonal)
 3815: 
 3816:         This geometrical property can be seen in two dimensions by plotting
 3817:         generated data-points:
 3818: 
 3819:         >>> mean = [0, 0]
 3820:         >>> cov = [[1, 0], [0, 100]]  # diagonal covariance
 3821: 
 3822:         Diagonal covariance means that points are oriented along x or y-axis:
 3823: 
 3824:         >>> from randomgen import Generator
 3825:         >>> rg = Generator()
 3826:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 3827:         >>> x, y = rg.multivariate_normal(mean, cov, 5000).T
 3828:         >>> plt.plot(x, y, 'x')
 3829:         >>> plt.axis('equal')
 3830:         >>> plt.show()
 3831: 
 3832:         Note that the covariance matrix must be positive semidefinite (a.k.a.
 3833:         nonnegative-definite). Otherwise, the behavior of this method is
 3834:         undefined and backwards compatibility is not guaranteed.
 3835: 
 3836:         References
 3837:         ----------
 3838:         .. [1] Papoulis, A., "Probability, Random Variables, and Stochastic
 3839:                Processes," 3rd ed., New York: McGraw-Hill, 1991.
 3840:         .. [2] Duda, R. O., Hart, P. E., and Stork, D. G., "Pattern
 3841:                Classification," 2nd ed., New York: Wiley, 2001.
 3842: 
 3843:         Examples
 3844:         --------
 3845:         >>> from randomgen import Generator
 3846:         >>> rg = Generator()
 3847:         >>> mean = (1, 2)
 3848:         >>> cov = [[1, 0], [0, 1]]
 3849:         >>> x = rg.multivariate_normal(mean, cov, (3, 3))
 3850:         >>> x.shape
 3851:         (3, 3, 2)
 3852: 
 3853:         The following is probably true, given that 0.6 is roughly twice the
 3854:         standard deviation:
 3855: 
 3856:         >>> list((x[0,0,:] - mean) < 0.6)
 3857:         [True, True] # random
 3858: 
 3859:         """

 3942: 
+3943:     def multinomial(self, object n, object pvals, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_105multinomial(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_104multinomial[] = "\n        multinomial(n, pvals, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from a multinomial distribution.\n\n        The multinomial distribution is a multivariate generalization of the\n        binomial distribution. Take an experiment with one of ``p``\n        possible outcomes. An example of such an experiment is throwing a dice,\n        where the outcome can be 1 through 6. Each sample drawn from the\n        distribution represents `n` such experiments. Its values,\n        ``X_i = [X_0, X_1, ..., X_p]``, represent the number of times the\n        outcome was ``i``.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        n : {int, array_like[int]}\n            Number of experiments.\n        pvals : sequence of floats, length p\n            Probabilities of each of the ``p`` different outcomes. These\n            must sum to 1 (however, the last element is always assumed to\n            account for the remaining probability, as long as\n            ``sum(pvals[:-1]) <= 1)``.\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. Default is None, in which case a\n            single value is returned.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray\n            The drawn samples, of shape *size*, if that was provided. If not,\n            the shape is ``(N,)``.\n\n            In other words, each entry ``out[i,j,...,:]`` is an N-dimensional\n            value drawn from the distribution.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Throw a dice 20 times:\n\n        >>> randomgen.generator.multinomial(20, [1/6.]*6, size=1)\n        array([[4, 1, 7, 5, 2, 1]])  # random\n\n        It landed 4 times on 1, once on 2, etc.\n\n        Now, throw the dice 20 times, and 20 times again:\n\n        >>> randomgen.generator.multinomial(20, [1/6.]*6, size=2)\n        array([[3, 4, 3, 3, 4, 3],\n               [2, 4, 3, 4, 0, 7]])  # random\n\n        For the f""irst run, we threw 3 times 1, 4 times 2, etc. For the second,\n        we threw 2 times 1, 4 times 2, etc.\n\n        Now, do one experiment throwing the dice 10 time, and 10 times again,\n        and another throwing the dice 20 times, and 20 times again:\n\n        >>> randomgen.generator.multinomial([[10], [20]], [1/6.]*6, size=2)\n        array([[[2, 4, 0, 1, 2, 1],\n                [1, 3, 0, 3, 1, 2]],\n               [[1, 4, 4, 4, 4, 3],\n                [3, 3, 2, 5, 5, 2]]])  # random\n\n        The first array shows the outcomes of throwing the dice 10 times, and\n        the second shows the outcomes from throwing the dice 20 times.\n\n        A loaded die is more likely to land on number 6:\n\n        >>> randomgen.generator.multinomial(100, [1/7.]*5 + [2/7.])\n        array([11, 16, 14, 17, 16, 26])  # random\n\n        The probability inputs should be normalized. As an implementation\n        detail, the value of the last entry is ignored and assumed to take\n        up any leftover probability mass, but this should not be relied on.\n        A biased coin which has twice as much weight on one side as on the\n        other should be sampled like so:\n\n        >>> randomgen.generator.multinomial(100, [1.0 / 3, 2.0 / 3])  # RIGHT\n        array([38, 62])  # random\n\n        not like:\n\n        >>> randomgen.generator.multinomial(100, [1.0, 2.0])  # WRONG\n        Traceback (most recent call last):\n        ValueError: pvals < 0, pvals > 1 or pvals contains NaNs\n\n        ";

 3944:         """
 3945:         multinomial(n, pvals, size=None)
 3946: 
 3947:         Draw samples from a multinomial distribution.
 3948: 
 3949:         The multinomial distribution is a multivariate generalization of the
 3950:         binomial distribution. Take an experiment with one of ``p``
 3951:         possible outcomes. An example of such an experiment is throwing a dice,
 3952:         where the outcome can be 1 through 6. Each sample drawn from the
 3953:         distribution represents `n` such experiments. Its values,
 3954:         ``X_i = [X_0, X_1, ..., X_p]``, represent the number of times the
 3955:         outcome was ``i``.
 3956: 
 3957:         Parameters
 3958:         ----------
 3959:         n : {int, array_like[int]}
 3960:             Number of experiments.
 3961:         pvals : sequence of floats, length p
 3962:             Probabilities of each of the ``p`` different outcomes. These
 3963:             must sum to 1 (however, the last element is always assumed to
 3964:             account for the remaining probability, as long as
 3965:             ``sum(pvals[:-1]) <= 1)``.
 3966:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 3967:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 3968:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. Default is None, in which case a
 3969:             single value is returned.
 3970: 
 3971:         Returns
 3972:         -------
 3973:         out : ndarray
 3974:             The drawn samples, of shape *size*, if that was provided. If not,
 3975:             the shape is ``(N,)``.
 3976: 
 3977:             In other words, each entry ``out[i,j,...,:]`` is an N-dimensional
 3978:             value drawn from the distribution.
 3979: 
 3980:         Examples
 3981:         --------
 3982:         Throw a dice 20 times:
 3983: 
 3984:         >>> randomgen.generator.multinomial(20, [1/6.]*6, size=1)
 3985:         array([[4, 1, 7, 5, 2, 1]])  # random
 3986: 
 3987:         It landed 4 times on 1, once on 2, etc.
 3988: 
 3989:         Now, throw the dice 20 times, and 20 times again:
 3990: 
 3991:         >>> randomgen.generator.multinomial(20, [1/6.]*6, size=2)
 3992:         array([[3, 4, 3, 3, 4, 3],
 3993:                [2, 4, 3, 4, 0, 7]])  # random
 3994: 
 3995:         For the first run, we threw 3 times 1, 4 times 2, etc. For the second,
 3996:         we threw 2 times 1, 4 times 2, etc.
 3997: 
 3998:         Now, do one experiment throwing the dice 10 time, and 10 times again,
 3999:         and another throwing the dice 20 times, and 20 times again:
 4000: 
 4001:         >>> randomgen.generator.multinomial([[10], [20]], [1/6.]*6, size=2)
 4002:         array([[[2, 4, 0, 1, 2, 1],
 4003:                 [1, 3, 0, 3, 1, 2]],
 4004:                [[1, 4, 4, 4, 4, 3],
 4005:                 [3, 3, 2, 5, 5, 2]]])  # random
 4006: 
 4007:         The first array shows the outcomes of throwing the dice 10 times, and
 4008:         the second shows the outcomes from throwing the dice 20 times.
 4009: 
 4010:         A loaded die is more likely to land on number 6:
 4011: 
 4012:         >>> randomgen.generator.multinomial(100, [1/7.]*5 + [2/7.])
 4013:         array([11, 16, 14, 17, 16, 26])  # random
 4014: 
 4015:         The probability inputs should be normalized. As an implementation
 4016:         detail, the value of the last entry is ignored and assumed to take
 4017:         up any leftover probability mass, but this should not be relied on.
 4018:         A biased coin which has twice as much weight on one side as on the
 4019:         other should be sampled like so:
 4020: 
 4021:         >>> randomgen.generator.multinomial(100, [1.0 / 3, 2.0 / 3])  # RIGHT
 4022:         array([38, 62])  # random
 4023: 
 4024:         not like:
 4025: 
 4026:         >>> randomgen.generator.multinomial(100, [1.0, 2.0])  # WRONG
 4027:         Traceback (most recent call last):
 4028:         ValueError: pvals < 0, pvals > 1 or pvals contains NaNs
 4029: 
 4030:         """
 4031: 
 4032:         cdef np.npy_intp d, i, sz, offset
 4033:         cdef np.ndarray parr, mnarr, on, temp_arr
 4034:         cdef double *pix
 4035:         cdef int64_t *mnix
 4036:         cdef int64_t ni
 4037:         cdef np.broadcast it
 4038:

 4094: 
+4095:     def dirichlet(self, object alpha, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_107dirichlet(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_106dirichlet[] = "\n        dirichlet(alpha, size=None)\n\n        Draw samples from the Dirichlet distribution.\n\n        Draw `size` samples of dimension k from a Dirichlet distribution. A\n        Dirichlet-distributed random variable can be seen as a multivariate\n        generalization of a Beta distribution. The Dirichlet distribution\n        is a conjugate prior of a multinomial distribution in Bayesian\n        inference.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        alpha : sequence of floats, length k\n            Parameter of the distribution (length ``k`` for sample of\n            length ``k``).\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape.  If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. Default is None, in which case a\n            vector of length ``k`` is returned.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        samples : ndarray,\n            The drawn samples, of shape ``(size, k)``.\n\n        Raises\n        -------\n        ValueError\n            If any value in ``alpha`` is less than or equal to zero.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The Dirichlet distribution is a distribution over vectors\n        :math:`x` that fulfil the conditions :math:`x_i>0` and\n        :math:`\\sum_{i=1}^k x_i = 1`.\n\n        The probability density function :math:`p` of a\n        Dirichlet-distributed random vector :math:`X` is\n        proportional to\n\n        .. math:: p(x) \\propto \\prod_{i=1}^{k}{x^{\\alpha_i-1}_i},\n\n        where :math:`\\alpha` is a vector containing the positive\n        concentration parameters.\n\n        The method uses the following property for computation: let :math:`Y`\n        be a random vector which has components that follow a standard gamma\n        distribution, then :math:`X = \\frac{1}{\\sum_{i=1}^k{Y_i}} Y`\n        is Dirichlet-distributed\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] David McKay, \"Information Theory, Inference and Learning""\n               Algorithms,\" chapter 23,\n               http://www.inference.org.uk/mackay/itila/\n        .. [2] Wikipedia, \"Dirichlet distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dirichlet_distribution\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Taking an example cited in Wikipedia, this distribution can be used if\n        one wanted to cut strings (each of initial length 1.0) into K pieces\n        with different lengths, where each piece had, on average, a designated\n        average length, but allowing some variation in the relative sizes of\n        the pieces.\n\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.dirichlet((10, 5, 3), 20).transpose()\n\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> plt.barh(range(20), s[0])\n        >>> plt.barh(range(20), s[1], left=s[0], color='g')\n        >>> plt.barh(range(20), s[2], left=s[0]+s[1], color='r')\n        >>> plt.title(\"Lengths of Strings\")\n\n        ";

  return __pyx_r;
}

static PyObject *__pyx_pf_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_106dirichlet(struct __pyx_obj_9randomgen_9generator_Generator *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_v_alpha, PyObject *__pyx_v_size) {

}

 4096:         """
 4097:         dirichlet(alpha, size=None)
 4098: 
 4099:         Draw samples from the Dirichlet distribution.
 4100: 
 4101:         Draw `size` samples of dimension k from a Dirichlet distribution. A
 4102:         Dirichlet-distributed random variable can be seen as a multivariate
 4103:         generalization of a Beta distribution. The Dirichlet distribution
 4104:         is a conjugate prior of a multinomial distribution in Bayesian
 4105:         inference.
 4106: 
 4107:         Parameters
 4108:         ----------
 4109:         alpha : sequence of floats, length k
 4110:             Parameter of the distribution (length ``k`` for sample of
 4111:             length ``k``).
 4112:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 4113:             Output shape.  If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n)``, then
 4114:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. Default is None, in which case a
 4115:             vector of length ``k`` is returned.
 4116: 
 4117:         Returns
 4118:         -------
 4119:         samples : ndarray,
 4120:             The drawn samples, of shape ``(size, k)``.
 4121: 
 4122:         Raises
 4123:         -------
 4124:         ValueError
 4125:             If any value in ``alpha`` is less than or equal to zero.
 4126: 
 4127:         Notes
 4128:         -----
 4129:         The Dirichlet distribution is a distribution over vectors
 4130:         :math:`x` that fulfil the conditions :math:`x_i>0` and
 4131:         :math:`\\sum_{i=1}^k x_i = 1`.
 4132: 
 4133:         The probability density function :math:`p` of a
 4134:         Dirichlet-distributed random vector :math:`X` is
 4135:         proportional to
 4136: 
 4137:         .. math:: p(x) \\propto \\prod_{i=1}^{k}{x^{\\alpha_i-1}_i},
 4138: 
 4139:         where :math:`\\alpha` is a vector containing the positive
 4140:         concentration parameters.
 4141: 
 4142:         The method uses the following property for computation: let :math:`Y`
 4143:         be a random vector which has components that follow a standard gamma
 4144:         distribution, then :math:`X = \\frac{1}{\\sum_{i=1}^k{Y_i}} Y`
 4145:         is Dirichlet-distributed
 4146: 
 4147:         References
 4148:         ----------
 4149:         .. [1] David McKay, "Information Theory, Inference and Learning
 4150:                Algorithms," chapter 23,
 4151:                http://www.inference.org.uk/mackay/itila/
 4152:         .. [2] Wikipedia, "Dirichlet distribution",
 4153:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dirichlet_distribution
 4154: 
 4155:         Examples
 4156:         --------
 4157:         Taking an example cited in Wikipedia, this distribution can be used if
 4158:         one wanted to cut strings (each of initial length 1.0) into K pieces
 4159:         with different lengths, where each piece had, on average, a designated
 4160:         average length, but allowing some variation in the relative sizes of
 4161:         the pieces.
 4162: 
 4163:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.dirichlet((10, 5, 3), 20).transpose()
 4164: 
 4165:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 4166:         >>> plt.barh(range(20), s[0])
 4167:         >>> plt.barh(range(20), s[1], left=s[0], color='g')
 4168:         >>> plt.barh(range(20), s[2], left=s[0]+s[1], color='r')
 4169:         >>> plt.title("Lengths of Strings")
 4170: 
 4171:         """
 4172: 
 4173:         # =================
 4174:         # Pure python algo
 4175:         # =================
 4176:         # alpha   = N.atleast_1d(alpha)
 4177:         # k       = alpha.size
 4178: 
 4179:         # if n == 1:
 4180:         #     val = N.zeros(k)
 4181:         #     for i in range(k):
 4182:         #         val[i]   = sgamma(alpha[i], n)
 4183:         #     val /= N.sum(val)
 4184:         # else:
 4185:         #     val = N.zeros((k, n))
 4186:         #     for i in range(k):
 4187:         #         val[i]   = sgamma(alpha[i], n)
 4188:         #     val /= N.sum(val, axis = 0)
 4189:         #     val = val.T
 4190:         # return val
 4191: 
 4192:         cdef np.npy_intp k, totsize, i, j
 4193:         cdef np.ndarray alpha_arr, val_arr
 4194:         cdef double *alpha_data
 4195:         cdef double *val_data
 4196:         cdef double acc, invacc
 4197: 
+4198:         k = len(alpha)
  __pyx_t_1 = PyObject_Length(__pyx_v_alpha); if (unlikely(__pyx_t_1 == ((Py_ssize_t)-1))) __PYX_ERR(0, 4198, __pyx_L1_error)
  __pyx_v_k = __pyx_t_1;

+4199:         alpha_arr = <np.ndarray>np.PyArray_FROMANY(alpha, np.NPY_DOUBLE, 1, 1, np.NPY_ARRAY_ALIGNED | np.NPY_ARRAY_C_CONTIGUOUS)

  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_2);
  __pyx_t_3 = __pyx_t_2;
  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_t_3);
  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_2); __pyx_t_2 = 0;
  __pyx_v_alpha_arr = ((PyArrayObject *)__pyx_t_3);
  __pyx_t_3 = 0;
