 4232:     # Shuffling and permutations:
+4233:     def shuffle(self, object x):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_109shuffle(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_v_x); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_108shuffle[] = "\n        shuffle(x)\n\n        Modify a sequence in-place by shuffling its contents.\n\n        This function only shuffles the array along the first axis of a\n        multi-dimensional array. The order of sub-arrays is changed but\n        their contents remains the same.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        x : array_like\n            The array or list to be shuffled.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        None\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        >>> arr = np.arange(10)\n        >>> randomgen.generator.shuffle(arr)\n        >>> arr\n        [1 7 5 2 9 4 3 6 0 8] # random\n\n        Multi-dimensional arrays are only shuffled along the first axis:\n\n        >>> arr = np.arange(9).reshape((3, 3))\n        >>> randomgen.generator.shuffle(arr)\n        >>> arr\n        array([[3, 4, 5], # random\n               [6, 7, 8],\n               [0, 1, 2]])\n\n        ";

 4234:         """
 4235:         shuffle(x)
 4236: 
 4237:         Modify a sequence in-place by shuffling its contents.
 4238: 
 4239:         This function only shuffles the array along the first axis of a
 4240:         multi-dimensional array. The order of sub-arrays is changed but
 4241:         their contents remains the same.
 4242: 
 4243:         Parameters
 4244:         ----------
 4245:         x : array_like
 4246:             The array or list to be shuffled.
 4247: 
 4248:         Returns
 4249:         -------
 4250:         None
 4251: 
 4252:         Examples
 4253:         --------
 4254:         >>> arr = np.arange(10)
 4255:         >>> randomgen.generator.shuffle(arr)
 4256:         >>> arr
 4257:         [1 7 5 2 9 4 3 6 0 8] # random
 4258: 
 4259:         Multi-dimensional arrays are only shuffled along the first axis:
 4260: 
 4261:         >>> arr = np.arange(9).reshape((3, 3))
 4262:         >>> randomgen.generator.shuffle(arr)
 4263:         >>> arr
 4264:         array([[3, 4, 5], # random
 4265:                [6, 7, 8],
 4266:                [0, 1, 2]])
 4267: 
 4268:         """
 4269:         cdef:

 4314:                              np.npy_intp itemsize, np.npy_intp stride,
 4315:                              char* data, char* buf):
 4316:         """
 4317:         Parameters
 4318:         ----------
 4319:         n
 4320:             Number of elements in data
 4321:         first
 4322:             First observation to shuffle. Shuffles n-1,
 4323:             n-2, ..., first, so that when first=1 the entire
 4324:             array is shuffled
 4325:         itemsize

+4363:     def permutation(self, object x):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_111permutation(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_v_x); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_110permutation[] = "\n        permutation(x)\n\n        Randomly permute a sequence, or return a permuted range.\n\n        If `x` is a multi-dimensional array, it is only shuffled along its\n        first index.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        x : int or array_like\n            If `x` is an integer, randomly permute ``np.arange(x)``.\n            If `x` is an array, make a copy and shuffle the elements\n            randomly.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray\n            Permuted sequence or array range.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        >>> from randomgen import Generator\n        >>> gen = Generator()\n        >>> gen.permutation(10)\n        array([1, 7, 4, 3, 0, 9, 2, 5, 8, 6]) # random\n\n        >>> gen.permutation([1, 4, 9, 12, 15])\n        array([15,  1,  9,  4, 12]) # random\n\n        >>> arr = np.arange(9).reshape((3, 3))\n        >>> gen.permutation(arr)\n        array([[6, 7, 8], # random\n               [0, 1, 2],\n               [3, 4, 5]])\n\n        ";

 4364:         """
 4365:         permutation(x)
 4366: 
 4367:         Randomly permute a sequence, or return a permuted range.
 4368: 
 4369:         If `x` is a multi-dimensional array, it is only shuffled along its
 4370:         first index.
 4371: 
 4372:         Parameters
 4373:         ----------
 4374:         x : int or array_like
 4375:             If `x` is an integer, randomly permute ``np.arange(x)``.
 4376:             If `x` is an array, make a copy and shuffle the elements
 4377:             randomly.
 4378: 
 4379:         Returns
 4380:         -------
 4381:         out : ndarray
 4382:             Permuted sequence or array range.
 4383: 
 4384:         Examples
 4385:         --------
 4386:         >>> from randomgen import Generator
 4387:         >>> gen = Generator()
 4388:         >>> gen.permutation(10)
 4389:         array([1, 7, 4, 3, 0, 9, 2, 5, 8, 6]) # random
 4390: 
 4391:         >>> gen.permutation([1, 4, 9, 12, 15])
 4392:         array([15,  1,  9,  4, 12]) # random
 4393: 
 4394:         >>> arr = np.arange(9).reshape((3, 3))
 4395:         >>> gen.permutation(arr)
 4396:         array([[6, 7, 8], # random
 4397:                [0, 1, 2],
 4398:                [3, 4, 5]])
 4399:

+4422:     def complex_normal(self, loc=0.0, gamma=1.0, relation=0.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_113complex_normal(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_9Generator_112complex_normal[] = "\n        complex_normal(loc=0.0, gamma=1.0, relation=0.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw random samples from a complex normal (Gaussian) distribution.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        loc : complex or array_like of complex\n            Mean of the distribution.\n        gamma : float, complex or array_like of float or complex\n            Variance of the distribution\n        relation : float, complex or array_like of float or complex\n            Relation between the two component normals\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``loc``, ``gamma`` and ``relation``\n            are all scalars. Otherwise,\n            ``np.broadcast(loc, gamma, relation).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized complex normal distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        randomgen.generator.normal : random values from a real-valued normal\n            distribution\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        **EXPERIMENTAL** Not part of official NumPy RandomState, may change until\n        formal release on PyPi.\n\n        Complex normals are generated from a bivariate normal where the\n        variance of the real component is 0.5 Re(gamma + relation), the\n        variance of the imaginary component is 0.5 Re(gamma - relation), and\n        the covariance between the two is 0.5 Im(relation). The implied\n        covariance matrix must be positive semi-definite and so both variances\n        must be zero and the covariance must be weakly smaller than the\n        product of the two standard deviations.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Wikipedia, \"Complex normal distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex""_normal_distribution\n        .. [2] Leigh J. Halliwell, \"Complex Random Variables\" in \"Casualty\n               Actuarial Society E-Forum\", Fall 2015.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.complex_normal(size=1000)\n\n        ";

 4423:         """
 4424:         complex_normal(loc=0.0, gamma=1.0, relation=0.0, size=None)
 4425: 
 4426:         Draw random samples from a complex normal (Gaussian) distribution.
 4427: 
 4428:         Parameters
 4429:         ----------
 4430:         loc : complex or array_like of complex
 4431:             Mean of the distribution.
 4432:         gamma : float, complex or array_like of float or complex
 4433:             Variance of the distribution
 4434:         relation : float, complex or array_like of float or complex
 4435:             Relation between the two component normals
 4436:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 4437:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 4438:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 4439:             a single value is returned if ``loc``, ``gamma`` and ``relation``
 4440:             are all scalars. Otherwise,
 4441:             ``np.broadcast(loc, gamma, relation).size`` samples are drawn.
 4442: 
 4443:         Returns
 4444:         -------
 4445:         out : ndarray or scalar
 4446:             Drawn samples from the parameterized complex normal distribution.
 4447: 
 4448:         See Also
 4449:         --------
 4450:         randomgen.generator.normal : random values from a real-valued normal
 4451:             distribution
 4452: 
 4453:         Notes
 4454:         -----
 4455:         **EXPERIMENTAL** Not part of official NumPy RandomState, may change until
 4456:         formal release on PyPi.
 4457: 
 4458:         Complex normals are generated from a bivariate normal where the
 4459:         variance of the real component is 0.5 Re(gamma + relation), the
 4460:         variance of the imaginary component is 0.5 Re(gamma - relation), and
 4461:         the covariance between the two is 0.5 Im(relation). The implied
 4462:         covariance matrix must be positive semi-definite and so both variances
 4463:         must be zero and the covariance must be weakly smaller than the
 4464:         product of the two standard deviations.
 4465: 
 4466:         References
 4467:         ----------
 4468:         .. [1] Wikipedia, "Complex normal distribution",
 4469:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_normal_distribution
 4470:         .. [2] Leigh J. Halliwell, "Complex Random Variables" in "Casualty
 4471:                Actuarial Society E-Forum", Fall 2015.
 4472: 
 4473:         Examples
 4474:         --------
 4475:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 4476: 
 4477:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.complex_normal(size=1000)
 4478: 
 4479:         """
 4480:         cdef np.ndarray ogamma, orelation, oloc, randoms, v_real, v_imag, rho
 4481:         cdef double *randoms_data
 4482:         cdef double fgamma_r, fgamma_i, frelation_r, frelation_i, frho, \
 4483:             fvar_r, fvar_i, floc_r, floc_i, f_real, f_imag, f_rho
 4484:         cdef np.npy_intp i, j, n, n2
 4485:         cdef np.broadcast it
 4486:

  __Pyx_DECREF(__pyx_t_1); __pyx_t_1 = 0;
  __pyx_v_oloc = ((PyArrayObject *)__pyx_t_2);
  __pyx_t_2 = 0;

+4587: cdef class ExtendedGenerator:
struct __pyx_obj_9randomgen_9generator_ExtendedGenerator {
  PyObject_HEAD
  PyObject *_bit_generator;
  bitgen_t _bitgen;
  binomial_t _binomial;
  PyObject *lock;
  PyObject *_generator;
};


 4588:     """
 4589:     ExtendedGenerator(bit_generator=None)
 4590: 
 4591:     Additional random value generator using a bit generator source.
 4592: 
 4593:     ``ExtendedGenerator`` exposes methods for generating random numbers
 4594:     from some distributions that are not in numpy.random.Generator.
 4595: 
 4596:     Parameters
 4597:     ----------
 4598:     bit_generator : BitGenerator, optional
 4599:         Bit generator to use as the core generator. If none is provided, uses
 4600:         PCG64(variant="cm-dxsm").
 4601: 
 4602:     See Also
 4603:     --------
 4604:     numpy.random.Generator
 4605:         The primary generator of random variates.
 4606: 
 4607:     Examples
 4608:     --------
 4609:     >>> from randomgen import ExtendedGenerator
 4610:     >>> rg = ExtendedGenerator()
 4611:     >>> rg.complex_normal()
 4612:     -0.203 + .936j  # random
 4613: 
 4614:     Using a specific generator
 4615: 
 4616:     >>> from randomgen import MT19937
 4617:     >>> rg = ExtendedGenerator(MT19937())
 4618: 
 4619:     Share a bit generator with numpy
 4620: 
 4621:     >>> from numpy.random import Generator, PCG64
 4622:     >>> pcg = PCG64()
 4623:     >>> gen = Generator(pcg)
 4624:     >>> eg = ExtendedGenerator(pcg)
 4625:     """
 4626: 
+4627:     cdef public object _bit_generator

/* Python wrapper */
static int __pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_17ExtendedGenerator_14_bit_generator_5__del__(PyObject *__pyx_v_self); /*proto*/

If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. Default is None, in which case a\n            single value is returned.\n        bits : int {32, 64}\n            Size of the unsigned integer to return, either 32 bit or 64 bit.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : uint or ndarray\n            Drawn samples.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        This method effectively exposes access to the raw underlying\n        pseudo-random number generator since these all produce unsigned\n        integers. In practice these are most useful for generating other\n        random numbers.\n        These should not be used to produce bounded random numbers by\n        simple truncation.\n        ";

 4718:             single value is returned.

 4730:         pseudo-random number generator since these all produce unsigned

 4764: 
 4765:     # Multivariate distributions:
+4766:     def multivariate_normal(self, mean, cov, size=None, check_valid="warn",
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_17ExtendedGenerator_15multivariate_normal(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_17ExtendedGenerator_14multivariate_normal[] = "\n        multivariate_normal(mean, cov, size=None, check_valid='warn', tol=1e-8, *, method='svd')\n\n        Draw random samples from a multivariate normal distribution.\n\n        The multivariate normal, multinormal or Gaussian distribution is a\n        generalization of the one-dimensional normal distribution to higher\n        dimensions. Such a distribution is specified by its mean and\n        covariance matrix. These parameters are analogous to the mean\n        (average or \"center\") and variance (standard deviation, or \"width,\"\n        squared) of the one-dimensional normal distribution.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        mean : array_like\n            Mean of the distribution. Must have shape (m1, m2, ..., mk, N) where\n            (m1, m2, ..., mk) would broadcast with (c1, c2, ..., cj).\n        cov : array_like\n            Covariance matrix of the distribution. It must be symmetric and\n            positive-semidefinite for proper sampling. Must have shape\n            (c1, c2, ..., cj, N, N) where (c1, c2, ..., cj) would broadcast\n            with (m1, m2, ..., mk).\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Given a shape of, for example, ``(m,n,k)``, ``m*n*k`` samples are\n            generated, and packed in an `m`-by-`n`-by-`k` arrangement.  Because\n            each sample is `N`-dimensional, the output shape is ``(m,n,k,N)``.\n            If no shape is specified, a single (`N`-D) sample is returned.\n        check_valid : { 'warn', 'raise', 'ignore' }, optional\n            Behavior when the covariance matrix is not positive semidefinite.\n        tol : float, optional\n            Tolerance when checking the singular values in covariance matrix.\n            cov is cast to double before the check.\n        method : { 'svd', 'eigh', 'cholesky'}, optional\n            The cov input is used to compute a factor matrix A such that\n            ``A @ A.T = cov``. This argument is used to select the method\n    ""        used to compute the factor matrix A. The default method 'svd' is\n            the slowest, while 'cholesky' is the fastest but less robust than\n            the slowest method. The method `eigh` uses eigen decomposition to\n            compute A and is faster than svd but slower than cholesky.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray\n            The drawn samples, of shape determined by broadcasting the\n            leading dimensions of mean and cov with size, if not None.\n            The final dimension is always N.\n\n            In other words, each entry ``out[i,j,...,:]`` is an N-dimensional\n            value drawn from the distribution.\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        The mean is a coordinate in N-dimensional space, which represents the\n        location where samples are most likely to be generated. This is\n        analogous to the peak of the bell curve for the one-dimensional or\n        univariate normal distribution.\n\n        Covariance indicates the level to which two variables vary together.\n        From the multivariate normal distribution, we draw N-dimensional\n        samples, :math:`X = [x_1, x_2, ... x_N]`. The covariance matrix\n        element :math:`C_{ij}` is the covariance of :math:`x_i` and :math:`x_j`.\n        The element :math:`C_{ii}` is the variance of :math:`x_i` (i.e. its\n        \"spread\").\n\n        Instead of specifying the full covariance matrix, popular\n        approximations include:\n\n          - Spherical covariance (`cov` is a multiple of the identity matrix)\n          - Diagonal covariance (`cov` has non-negative elements, and only on\n            the diagonal)\n\n        This geometrical property can be seen in two dimensions by plotting\n        generated data-points:\n\n        >>> mean = [0, 0]\n        >>> cov = [[1, 0], [0, 100]]  # diagonal covariance\n\n        Diagonal covariance means that points are oriented along x or y-axis:\n\n        >>> from randomgen import Ge""nerator\n        >>> rg = Generator()\n        >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n        >>> x, y = rg.multivariate_normal(mean, cov, 5000).T\n        >>> plt.plot(x, y, 'x')\n        >>> plt.axis('equal')\n        >>> plt.show()\n\n        Note that the covariance matrix must be positive semidefinite (a.k.a.\n        nonnegative-definite). Otherwise, the behavior of this method is\n        undefined and backwards compatibility is not guaranteed.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Papoulis, A., \"Probability, Random Variables, and Stochastic\n               Processes,\" 3rd ed., New York: McGraw-Hill, 1991.\n        .. [2] Duda, R. O., Hart, P. E., and Stork, D. G., \"Pattern\n               Classification,\" 2nd ed., New York: Wiley, 2001.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        >>> from randomgen import Generator\n        >>> rg = Generator()\n        >>> mean = (1, 2)\n        >>> cov = [[1, 0], [0, 1]]\n        >>> x = rg.multivariate_normal(mean, cov, (3, 3))\n        >>> x.shape\n        (3, 3, 2)\n\n        The following is probably true, given that 0.6 is roughly twice the\n        standard deviation:\n\n        >>> list((x[0,0,:] - mean) < 0.6)\n        [True, True] # random\n\n        ";
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_17ExtendedGenerator_15multivariate_normal(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds) {
  PyObject *__pyx_v_mean = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_v_cov = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_v_size = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_v_check_valid = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_v_tol = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_v_method = 0;
  PyObject *__pyx_r = 0;
  __Pyx_RefNannyDeclarations
  __Pyx_RefNannySetupContext("multivariate_normal (wrapper)", 0);
  {
    static PyObject **__pyx_pyargnames[] = {&__pyx_n_s_mean,&__pyx_n_s_cov,&__pyx_n_s_size,&__pyx_n_s_check_valid,&__pyx_n_s_tol,&__pyx_n_s_method,0};
    PyObject* values[6] = {0,0,0,0,0,0};
    values[2] = ((PyObject *)Py_None);
    values[3] = ((PyObject *)__pyx_n_u_warn);

/*  */
struct __pyx_obj_9randomgen_9generator___pyx_scope_struct_1_multivariate_normal {
  PyObject_HEAD
  PyObject *__pyx_v_tol;
};


 4767:                             tol=1e-8, *, method="svd"):
 4768:         """
 4769:         multivariate_normal(mean, cov, size=None, check_valid='warn', tol=1e-8, *, method='svd')
 4770: 
 4771:         Draw random samples from a multivariate normal distribution.
 4772: 
 4773:         The multivariate normal, multinormal or Gaussian distribution is a
 4774:         generalization of the one-dimensional normal distribution to higher
 4775:         dimensions. Such a distribution is specified by its mean and
 4776:         covariance matrix. These parameters are analogous to the mean
 4777:         (average or "center") and variance (standard deviation, or "width,"
 4778:         squared) of the one-dimensional normal distribution.
 4779: 
 4780:         Parameters
 4781:         ----------
 4782:         mean : array_like
 4783:             Mean of the distribution. Must have shape (m1, m2, ..., mk, N) where
 4784:             (m1, m2, ..., mk) would broadcast with (c1, c2, ..., cj).
 4785:         cov : array_like
 4786:             Covariance matrix of the distribution. It must be symmetric and
 4787:             positive-semidefinite for proper sampling. Must have shape
 4788:             (c1, c2, ..., cj, N, N) where (c1, c2, ..., cj) would broadcast
 4789:             with (m1, m2, ..., mk).
 4790:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 4791:             Given a shape of, for example, ``(m,n,k)``, ``m*n*k`` samples are
 4792:             generated, and packed in an `m`-by-`n`-by-`k` arrangement.  Because
 4793:             each sample is `N`-dimensional, the output shape is ``(m,n,k,N)``.
 4794:             If no shape is specified, a single (`N`-D) sample is returned.
 4795:         check_valid : { 'warn', 'raise', 'ignore' }, optional
 4796:             Behavior when the covariance matrix is not positive semidefinite.
 4797:         tol : float, optional
 4798:             Tolerance when checking the singular values in covariance matrix.
 4799:             cov is cast to double before the check.
 4800:         method : { 'svd', 'eigh', 'cholesky'}, optional
 4801:             The cov input is used to compute a factor matrix A such that
 4802:             ``A @ A.T = cov``. This argument is used to select the method
 4803:             used to compute the factor matrix A. The default method 'svd' is
 4804:             the slowest, while 'cholesky' is the fastest but less robust than
 4805:             the slowest method. The method `eigh` uses eigen decomposition to
 4806:             compute A and is faster than svd but slower than cholesky.
 4807: 
 4808:         Returns
 4809:         -------
 4810:         out : ndarray
 4811:             The drawn samples, of shape determined by broadcasting the
 4812:             leading dimensions of mean and cov with size, if not None.
 4813:             The final dimension is always N.
 4814: 
 4815:             In other words, each entry ``out[i,j,...,:]`` is an N-dimensional
 4816:             value drawn from the distribution.
 4817: 
 4818:         Notes
 4819:         -----
 4820:         The mean is a coordinate in N-dimensional space, which represents the
 4821:         location where samples are most likely to be generated. This is
 4822:         analogous to the peak of the bell curve for the one-dimensional or
 4823:         univariate normal distribution.
 4824: 
 4825:         Covariance indicates the level to which two variables vary together.
 4826:         From the multivariate normal distribution, we draw N-dimensional
 4827:         samples, :math:`X = [x_1, x_2, ... x_N]`. The covariance matrix
 4828:         element :math:`C_{ij}` is the covariance of :math:`x_i` and :math:`x_j`.
 4829:         The element :math:`C_{ii}` is the variance of :math:`x_i` (i.e. its
 4830:         "spread").
 4831: 
 4832:         Instead of specifying the full covariance matrix, popular
 4833:         approximations include:
 4834: 
 4835:           - Spherical covariance (`cov` is a multiple of the identity matrix)
 4836:           - Diagonal covariance (`cov` has non-negative elements, and only on
 4837:             the diagonal)
 4838: 
 4839:         This geometrical property can be seen in two dimensions by plotting
 4840:         generated data-points:
 4841: 
 4842:         >>> mean = [0, 0]
 4843:         >>> cov = [[1, 0], [0, 100]]  # diagonal covariance
 4844: 
 4845:         Diagonal covariance means that points are oriented along x or y-axis:
 4846: 
 4847:         >>> from randomgen import Generator
 4848:         >>> rg = Generator()
 4849:         >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 4850:         >>> x, y = rg.multivariate_normal(mean, cov, 5000).T
 4851:         >>> plt.plot(x, y, 'x')
 4852:         >>> plt.axis('equal')
 4853:         >>> plt.show()
 4854: 
 4855:         Note that the covariance matrix must be positive semidefinite (a.k.a.
 4856:         nonnegative-definite). Otherwise, the behavior of this method is
 4857:         undefined and backwards compatibility is not guaranteed.
 4858: 
 4859:         References
 4860:         ----------
 4861:         .. [1] Papoulis, A., "Probability, Random Variables, and Stochastic
 4862:                Processes," 3rd ed., New York: McGraw-Hill, 1991.
 4863:         .. [2] Duda, R. O., Hart, P. E., and Stork, D. G., "Pattern
 4864:                Classification," 2nd ed., New York: Wiley, 2001.
 4865: 
 4866:         Examples
 4867:         --------
 4868:         >>> from randomgen import Generator
 4869:         >>> rg = Generator()
 4870:         >>> mean = (1, 2)
 4871:         >>> cov = [[1, 0], [0, 1]]
 4872:         >>> x = rg.multivariate_normal(mean, cov, (3, 3))
 4873:         >>> x.shape
 4874:         (3, 3, 2)
 4875: 
 4876:         The following is probably true, given that 0.6 is roughly twice the
 4877:         standard deviation:
 4878: 
 4879:         >>> list((x[0,0,:] - mean) < 0.6)
 4880:         [True, True] # random
 4881: 
 4882:         """

  } else {

 4968: 
+4969:     def complex_normal(self, loc=0.0, gamma=1.0, relation=0.0, size=None):
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_17ExtendedGenerator_17complex_normal(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_9randomgen_9generator_17ExtendedGenerator_16complex_normal[] = "\n        complex_normal(loc=0.0, gamma=1.0, relation=0.0, size=None)\n\n        Draw random samples from a complex normal (Gaussian) distribution.\n\n        Parameters\n        ----------\n        loc : complex or array_like of complex\n            Mean of the distribution.\n        gamma : float, complex or array_like of float or complex\n            Variance of the distribution\n        relation : float, complex or array_like of float or complex\n            Relation between the two component normals\n        size : int or tuple of ints, optional\n            Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then\n            ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),\n            a single value is returned if ``loc``, ``gamma`` and ``relation``\n            are all scalars. Otherwise,\n            ``np.broadcast(loc, gamma, relation).size`` samples are drawn.\n\n        Returns\n        -------\n        out : ndarray or scalar\n            Drawn samples from the parameterized complex normal distribution.\n\n        See Also\n        --------\n        numpy.random.Generator.normal : random values from a real-valued\n            normal distribution\n\n        Notes\n        -----\n        Complex normals are generated from a bivariate normal where the\n        variance of the real component is 0.5 Re(gamma + relation), the\n        variance of the imaginary component is 0.5 Re(gamma - relation), and\n        the covariance between the two is 0.5 Im(relation). The implied\n        covariance matrix must be positive semi-definite and so both variances\n        must be zero and the covariance must be weakly smaller than the\n        product of the two standard deviations.\n\n        References\n        ----------\n        .. [1] Wikipedia, \"Complex normal distribution\",\n               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_normal_distribution\n        .. [2] Leigh J. Halliwell, \"Complex Random Variables\" in \"Casualty\n              "" Actuarial Society E-Forum\", Fall 2015.\n\n        Examples\n        --------\n        Draw samples from the distribution:\n\n        >>> s = randomgen.generator.complex_normal(size=1000)\n\n        ";
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_9randomgen_9generator_17ExtendedGenerator_17complex_normal(PyObject *__pyx_v_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds) {

        case  4: values[3] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 3);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  3: values[2] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 2);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  2: values[1] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 1);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  1: values[0] = PyTuple_GET_ITEM(__pyx_args, 0);
        CYTHON_FALLTHROUGH;
        case  0: break;
        default: goto __pyx_L5_argtuple_error;
      }
    }
    __pyx_v_loc = values[0];
    __pyx_v_gamma = values[1];
    __pyx_v_relation = values[2];
    __pyx_v_size = values[3];
  }
  goto __pyx_L4_argument_unpacking_done;
  __pyx_L5_argtuple_error:;
  __Pyx_RaiseArgtupleInvalid("complex_normal", 0, 0, 4, PyTuple_GET_SIZE(__pyx_args)); __PYX_ERR(0, 4969, __pyx_L3_error)
  __pyx_L3_error:;

  __Pyx_RefNannyFinishContext();

 4970:         """
 4971:         complex_normal(loc=0.0, gamma=1.0, relation=0.0, size=None)
 4972: 
 4973:         Draw random samples from a complex normal (Gaussian) distribution.
 4974: 
 4975:         Parameters
 4976:         ----------
 4977:         loc : complex or array_like of complex
 4978:             Mean of the distribution.
 4979:         gamma : float, complex or array_like of float or complex
 4980:             Variance of the distribution
 4981:         relation : float, complex or array_like of float or complex
 4982:             Relation between the two component normals
 4983:         size : int or tuple of ints, optional
 4984:             Output shape. If the given shape is, e.g., ``(m, n, k)``, then
 4985:             ``m * n * k`` samples are drawn. If size is ``None`` (default),
 4986:             a single value is returned if ``loc``, ``gamma`` and ``relation``
 4987:             are all scalars. Otherwise,
 4988:             ``np.broadcast(loc, gamma, relation).size`` samples are drawn.
 4989: 
 4990:         Returns
 4991:         -------
 4992:         out : ndarray or scalar
 4993:             Drawn samples from the parameterized complex normal distribution.
 4994: 
 4995:         See Also
 4996:         --------
 4997:         numpy.random.Generator.normal : random values from a real-valued
 4998:             normal distribution
 4999: 
 5000:         Notes
 5001:         -----
 5002:         Complex normals are generated from a bivariate normal where the
 5003:         variance of the real component is 0.5 Re(gamma + relation), the
 5004:         variance of the imaginary component is 0.5 Re(gamma - relation), and
 5005:         the covariance between the two is 0.5 Im(relation). The implied
 5006:         covariance matrix must be positive semi-definite and so both variances
 5007:         must be zero and the covariance must be weakly smaller than the
 5008:         product of the two standard deviations.
 5009: 
 5010:         References
 5011:         ----------
 5012:         .. [1] Wikipedia, "Complex normal distribution",
 5013:                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_normal_distribution
 5014:         .. [2] Leigh J. Halliwell, "Complex Random Variables" in "Casualty
 5015:                Actuarial Society E-Forum", Fall 2015.
 5016: 
 5017:         Examples
 5018:         --------
 5019:         Draw samples from the distribution:
 5020: 
 5021:         >>> s = randomgen.generator.complex_normal(size=1000)
 5022: 
 5023:         """
 5024:         cdef np.ndarray ogamma, orelation, oloc, randoms, v_real, v_imag, rho
 5025:         cdef double *randoms_data
 5026:         cdef double fgamma_r, fgamma_i, frelation_r, frelation_i, frho, \
 5027:             fvar_r, fvar_i, floc_r, floc_i, f_real, f_imag, f_rho
 5028:         cdef np.npy_intp i, j, n, n2
 5029:         cdef np.broadcast it
 5030:

  __pyx_t_2 = 0;
